subject: RE: Hello from Stanley Black & Decker - Unconscious Bias
body:
Hello!  Kelly – TY for taking the time to map out the plans.  In summary, for Stanley Black & Decker purposes:
 
Intro to MUB:  we are interested in seeing the revised e-learning as we are still using the original elearning for all new hires.
The 3 hour workshop we have is “MUB in the Workplace” – I’m not sure of the replacement, if any
Very interested in the subscription model pricing
 
As far as the “pilot” which was brought to the table, I am not sure where that fits in all this.  We are truly starting from scratch.  Please stay in touch with your progress on the above!
 
Karen Rubano  
 
Global Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Center of Excellence
Stanley Black & Decker
860-304-1228
 
www.stanleyblackanddecker.com
https://www.stanleyblackanddecker.com/careers/working-here
https://www.stanleyblackanddecker.com/who-we-are/our-culture
 
 
From:
 Kelly Salek <k.salek@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, August 17, 2022 12:27 AM
To:
 Rubano, Karen <Karen.Rubano@sbdinc.com>; Tahitia Timmons <t.timmons@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Conner Williams <c.williams@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Hello from Stanley Black & Decker - Unconscious Bias
 
***CAUTION: EXTERNAL MESSAGE***
Karen & Tahitia – 
Thank you for all the clarification below…I am happy to step in a share a few insights from the Product, Design, and Development department at LCW.
 
Currently, we are revamping the look and feel of our online learnings, including the 
Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias
 and accompanying microlearnings on 
Managing Bias in Performance Reviews
 and 
Talent Reviews
 (see table below for full list). The content for all the learnings is in the process of being reviewed and undergoing a research analysis (determining the relevancy and accuracy of the research documentation…some historical documentation is still quite relevant).  
 
Additionally, we have been working on a follow-up to the 
Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias 
that takes the information to the next level, integrating 
habits for practicing conscious inclusion
 and the power of neuroplasticity (
neuroplasticity shapes our processes of behavioral change
). This is like a 201 course on managing bias (see new build below)—Conscious Inclusion. 
 
Maintenance Schedule
Course
Time
Est. Delivery Date
Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias
20-30 Mins
Mid/End October
Managing Bias in Talent Review
10 Mins
October
Managing Bias in Performance Reviews
10 Mins
October
Conscious Inclusion **
NEW BUILD
 – See concepts below**
20-30 Mins
Early/Mid November
Hiring & Promoting Top Talent
20 Mins
November
Hiring & Promoting Top Talent (Microlearning Series)
10 Min Each (x3)
November
Culture & Identity
20-30 Mins
December
 
Here are the storyboard concepts. During design and development, often we include organizations that want this type of learning to be included in the design process/content review and piloting…of course this includes a price break. For more information, let me know, we can organize a meeting to better align on the cost and process for how this works. Conner Williams is our resident expert in our new course design/development company integrations (cc’d here) as well as our bundled Learning path packages.  
 
 
Lastly, you asked about LCWs Learning platform. We have heard that although there is still a need for one-off purchasing of courses, companies are in need of learning experiences, something that continues and reinforces the need for DEIB experiential learning. With that in mind, we will be offering Learning Path Experiences that provide organizations with learning opportunities that can be used all year long…this might include 1-2 online learning courses, 1-2 microlearnings, articles and trends, and inclusion tips. All these things would be available through a subscription-based model using a cloud-based platform. The product is still in review and aims to be released in November…I’ll have the subscription model pricing done in two weeks.   
 
I am happy to share more about any of the individual projects mentioned above and walk-through the process of being a part of the development of content and/or a pilot [company] participant for the learning platform. 
Best!!!
 
 
-
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
KELLY SALEK
Director of Instructional Design
LCW

Lake Forest, IL 60045

Subject:
 Hello from Stanley Black & Decker - Unconscious Bias
 
Hi Tahitia and Kelly!  I hope all is well and you are surviving multiple heat waves throughout the US 
😊
 
Next week, a small group of SBD DEI and L&D practitioners are starting to discuss how to influence UB awareness across the enterprise.  All agree we have reached the LCW MUBW shelf-life, and all agree we must find a way to deliver a sustainable drip of content to our SBD employees.  Although Managers continue to be a primary target audience, we must think beyond Managers to our independent contributors and our manufacturing population.  All said, I have 3 questions:
 
Is LCW updating the 30 minute UB e-learning introduction that currently all new SBD hires experience? 
The only general UB offer I see on the recent document Tahitia sent me (current micro-learnings, elearnings, workshops) is pictured below.  Many of the research and data dates are quite old – some over 10 years old, many 2014-2017.  Is this product being updated?
I know you are working on a pilot proposal for us to take a look at – how is progress?
 
There is no doubt we have interest in building an UB experience.  LinkedIn learning will be one aspect but we need more.  We need to be cost conscious and yet we need to deliver – a fine balance.  TY for any info you can provide!
 
Karen
 
 
Karen Rubano  
 
Global Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Center of Excellence
Stanley Black & Decker
860-304-1228

subject: RE: Hello from Stanley Black & Decker - Unconscious Bias
body:
Karen & Tahitia – 
Thank you for all the clarification below…I am happy to step in a share a few insights from the Product, Design, and Development department at LCW.
 
Currently, we are revamping the look and feel of our online learnings, including the 
Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias
 and accompanying microlearnings on 
Managing Bias in Performance Reviews
 and 
Talent Reviews
 (see table below for full list). The content for all the learnings is in the process of being reviewed and undergoing a research analysis (determining the relevancy and accuracy of the research documentation…some historical documentation is still quite relevant).  
 
Additionally, we have been working on a follow-up to the 
Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias 
that takes the information to the next level, integrating 
habits for practicing conscious inclusion
 and the power of neuroplasticity (
neuroplasticity shapes our processes of behavioral change
). This is like a 201 course on managing bias (see new build below)—Conscious Inclusion. 
 
Maintenance Schedule
Course
Time
Est. Delivery Date
Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias
20-30 Mins
Mid/End October
Managing Bias in Talent Review
10 Mins
October
Managing Bias in Performance Reviews
10 Mins
October
Conscious Inclusion **
NEW BUILD
 – See concepts below**
20-30 Mins
Early/Mid November
Hiring & Promoting Top Talent
20 Mins
November
Hiring & Promoting Top Talent (Microlearning Series)
10 Min Each (x3)
November
Culture & Identity
20-30 Mins
December
 
Here are the storyboard concepts. During design and development, often we include organizations that want this type of learning to be included in the design process/content review and piloting…of course this includes a price break. For more information, let me know, we can organize a meeting to better align on the cost and process for how this works. Conner Williams is our resident expert in our new course design/development company integrations (cc’d here) as well as our bundled Learning path packages.  
 
 
Lastly, you asked about LCWs Learning platform. We have heard that although there is still a need for one-off purchasing of courses, companies are in need of learning experiences, something that continues and reinforces the need for DEIB experiential learning. With that in mind, we will be offering Learning Path Experiences that provide organizations with learning opportunities that can be used all year long…this might include 1-2 online learning courses, 1-2 microlearnings, articles and trends, and inclusion tips. All these things would be available through a subscription-based model using a cloud-based platform. The product is still in review and aims to be released in November…I’ll have the subscription model pricing done in two weeks.   
 
I am happy to share more about any of the individual projects mentioned above and walk-through the process of being a part of the development of content and/or a pilot [company] participant for the learning platform. 
Best!!!
 
 
-
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
KELLY SALEK
Director of Instructional Design
LCW 
100 S Saunders Rd, Suite 150
Lake Forest, IL 60045
  
 
 
Direct: +1.630.234.7807

 Hello from Stanley Black & Decker - Unconscious Bias
 
Hi Tahitia and Kelly!  I hope all is well and you are surviving multiple heat waves throughout the US 
😊
 
Next week, a small group of SBD DEI and L&D practitioners are starting to discuss how to influence UB awareness across the enterprise.  All agree we have reached the LCW MUBW shelf-life, and all agree we must find a way to deliver a sustainable drip of content to our SBD employees.  Although Managers continue to be a primary target audience, we must think beyond Managers to our independent contributors and our manufacturing population.  All said, I have 3 questions:
 
Is LCW updating the 30 minute UB e-learning introduction that currently all new SBD hires experience? 
The only general UB offer I see on the recent document Tahitia sent me (current micro-learnings, elearnings, workshops) is pictured below.  Many of the research and data dates are quite old – some over 10 years old, many 2014-2017.  Is this product being updated?
I know you are working on a pilot proposal for us to take a look at – how is progress?
 
There is no doubt we have interest in building an UB experience.  LinkedIn learning will be one aspect but we need more.  We need to be cost conscious and yet we need to deliver – a fine balance.  TY for any info you can provide!
 
Karen

To:
 Tahitia Timmons <t.timmons@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 FW: Hello from Stanley Black & Decker - Unconscious Bias
 
THIS IS GOING TO BE MY RESPONSE…OK…thoughts?
 
Karen & Tahitia – 
Thank you for all the clarification below…I am happy to step in a share a few insights from the Product, Design, and Development department at LCW.
 
Currently, we are revamping the look and feel of our online learnings, including the 
Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias
 and accompanying microlearnings on 
Managing Bias in Performance Reviews
 and 
Talent Reviews
 (see table below for full list). The content for all the learnings is in the process of being reviewed and undergoing a research analysis (determining the relevancy and accuracy of the research documentation…some historical documentation is still quite relevant).  
 
Additionally, we have been working on a follow-up to the 
Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias 
that takes the information to the next level, integrating 
habits for practicing conscious inclusion
 and the power of neuroplasticity (
neuroplasticity shapes our processes of behavioral change
). This is like a 201 course on managing bias (see new build below)—Conscious Inclusion. 
 
Maintenance Schedule
Course
Time
Est. Delivery Date
Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias
20-30 Mins
Mid/End October
Managing Bias in Talent Review
10 Mins
October
Managing Bias in Performance Reviews
10 Mins
October
Conscious Inclusion **
NEW BUILD
 – See concepts below**
20-30 Mins
Early/Mid November
Hiring & Promoting Top Talent
20 Mins
November
Hiring & Promoting Top Talent (Microlearning Series)
10 Min Each (x3)
November
Culture & Identity
20-30 Mins
December
 
Here are the storyboard concepts. During design and development, often we include organizations that want this type of learning to be included in the design process/content review and piloting…of course this includes a price break. For more information, let me know, we can organize a meeting to better align on the cost and process for how this works. Conner Williams is our resident expert in our new course design/development company integrations (cc’d here).  
 
 
Lastly, you asked about LCWs Learning platform. We have heard that although there is still a need for one-off purchasing of courses, companies are in need of learning experiences, something that continues and reinforces the need for DEIB experiential learning. With that in mind, we will be offering 
Learning Path Experiences
 (see sample image below) that provide organizations with learning opportunities that can be used all year long…this might include 1-2 online learning courses, 1-2 microlearnings, articles and trends, and inclusion tips. All these things would be available through a subscription-based model using a cloud-based platform. The product is still in review and aims to be released in November.   
 
 
I am happy to share more about any of the individual projects mentioned above (updated course, new course build, learning platform) and walk-through the process of being a part of the development of content and/or a pilot [company] participant for the learning platform. This might be just the kind of conversation and plan SBD needs to integrate the learnings from past LCW experiences, new learning opportunities from LCW and your LinkedIn Learning plan. 
 
Best!!!

subject: Let's talk about religious inclusion in the workplace
body:
Bring your questions and insights to this LCW live stream session - August 25th, 2022 at 2pm CST. 
 
 
 
Register to attend!
 
Join the conversation with LCW!
Live Stream Details:
 
Thursday, August 25th | 2pm CST (Q&A to follow)
Description:
 
While a person’s faith or non-faith is a deeply personal experience, it is also part of the authentic, intersectional identity they bring to the workplace. Yet, many organizations do not consider this important part of workers’ identities outside the Christian faith. In practicing cultural competency, it is crucial that organizations move beyond religious tolerance and toward inclusion­­—especially for non-Christian faiths and non-faiths—to ensure equitable policies for their diverse communities.
In this conversation, Culture Moments host Larry Baker (he/him) and DEI consultant Rahimeh Ramizany (she/her) delve into the complexities of faith in the workplace, drawing on Rahimeh’s experience as a consultant, speaker, DEI expert, and multiethnic, neurodiverse, visibly Muslim American woman.
Please use the button above to register for this complimentary live stream. We'll see you there!
 
 
 
 
Copyright © 2022 Language & Culture Worldwide, LLC, All rights reserved.
Our mailing address is:
100 S Saunders Rd, Suite 150
Lake Forest, IL 60045
Want to change how you receive these emails?
You can 
update your preferences
 or 
unsubscribe from this list
.

Here are the storyboard concepts. During design and development, often we include organizations that want this type of learning to be included in the design process/content review and piloting…of course this includes a price break. For more information, let me know, we can organize a meeting to better align on the cost and process for how this works. Conner Williams is our resident expert in our new course design/development company integrations (cc’d here).  
 
 
Lastly, you asked about LCWs Learning platform. We have heard that although there is still a need for one-off purchasing of courses, companies are in need of learning experiences, something that continues and reinforces the need for DEIB experiential learning. With that in mind, we will be offering 
Learning Path Experiences
 (see sample image below) that provide organizations with learning opportunities that can be used all year long…this might include 1-2 online learning courses, 1-2 microlearnings, articles and trends, and inclusion tips. All these things would be available through a subscription-based model using a cloud-based platform. The product is still in review and aims to be released in November.   
 
 
I am happy to share more about any of the individual projects mentioned above (updated course, new course build, learning platform) and walk-through the process of being a part of the development of content and/or a pilot [company] participant for the learning platform. This might be just the kind of conversation and plan SBD needs to integrate the learnings from past LCW experiences, new learning opportunities from LCW and your LinkedIn Learning plan. 
 
Best!!!

Hi Tahitia and Kelly!  I hope all is well and you are surviving multiple heat waves throughout the US 
😊
 
Next week, a small group of SBD DEI and L&D practitioners are starting to discuss how to influence UB awareness across the enterprise.  All agree we have reached the LCW MUBW shelf-life, and all agree we must find a way to deliver a sustainable drip of content to our SBD employees.  Although Managers continue to be a primary target audience, we must think beyond Managers to our independent contributors and our manufacturing population.  All said, I have 3 questions:
 
Is LCW updating the 30 minute UB e-learning introduction that currently all new SBD hires experience? 
The only general UB offer I see on the recent document Tahitia sent me (current micro-learnings, elearnings, workshops) is pictured below.  Many of the research and data dates are quite old – some over 10 years old, many 2014-2017.  Is this product being updated?
I know you are working on a pilot proposal for us to take a look at – how is progress?
 
There is no doubt we have interest in building an UB experience.  LinkedIn learning will be one aspect but we need more.  We need to be cost conscious and yet we need to deliver – a fine balance.  TY for any info you can provide!
 
Karen

Subject:
 Inclusion Learning Journeys.pptx
Importance:
 High
 
Hello folks!
Attached is an updated effort to incorporate feedback on what people liked/didn’t like in the “UTBE” Learning Journey. Of course – eventually a gorgeous formatting job from Keri/Kelly will also be needed. 
😊
 
But for now… as a first step…
 
Since each of you has expressed interest in seeing what journey maps aligned to the SCI model and Inclusive Leadership might look like–I’d love your thoughts on the attached. It is by no means PRETTY (at all) – but note I focused on:
color-coding the Inclusive Leadership Competency Framework to align with the already agreed upon graphic for the “Sustainable Culture of Inclusion Model”
creating distinct inclusive leadership learning journeys for 3 groups: 
All audiences including individual contributors 
Senior leaders
Middle managers
 
Tahitia, Andrea, Sarah, Dan and Tamara
 – I’d love you to see if you like the courses listed under each, and what you might change.
 
Chuck, Alisa, Kell, Nicole and Melissa
 – I’d welcome your thoughts on the overall concepts here, knowing that I’ve tried to capture my expertise and experience for you in a transferrable way.
 
If we are headed in the right direction – I will format the “Bias Learning Journeys” attached. For now I’ve just documented the courses, trying to minimize (but not necessarily completely eliminate) redundancy with the Inclusive Leadership Journeys so that you can sell both to a given client. 
 
I’ll set up time to talk through these with some of you next week. 
 
 
Thank you 
😊
M

subject: RE: Hello from Stanley Black & Decker - Unconscious Bias
body:
Hi, and Happy Friday!
 
One point of confusion:  I caution us making reference to what we have (MUBW) with the goal of turning “it” from the 3 hour live workshop to a micro-learnings design.  We agreed the content is 5+ years old and has reached its shelf life.  That said, our interest is to understand:
 
What will be LCW’s future 
UB offer 
(for managers and employees) in a micro-learning format?
Will LCW revise the 30 minute video SBD has used for new hires? And if so, when will it be ready?
 
We discussed a pilot proposal based on LCW’s new content and learning platform.  We are interested in what that pilot would look like and cost.  I hope this aligns to what you are coming up with.  Happy to chat.
 
Karen 
 
Karen Rubano  
 
Global Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Center of Excellence
Stanley Black & Decker
860-304-1228
 
www.stanleyblackanddecker.com
https://www.stanleyblackanddecker.com/careers/working-here
https://www.stanleyblackanddecker.com/who-we-are/our-culture
 
 
From:
 Tahitia Timmons <t.timmons@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Friday, August 12, 2022 12:17 PM
To:
 Rubano, Karen <Karen.Rubano@sbdinc.com>; Kelly Salek <k.salek@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Hello from Stanley Black & Decker - Unconscious Bias
 
***CAUTION: EXTERNAL MESSAGE***
Hi Karen, 
In answer to your questions: 
#1&2. The e-learning UB offering is currently being revised and refreshed. Unfortunately, what we currently are showing is the previous version and does not showcase the new look and or the updated content. However, I can share some preview slides of another course to help give you a feel for what the new training will look like. 
#3. Yes, we are working on that proposal for your train-the-trainer. I am attaching the original TTT LCW schedule for that program so you have something as a reference for our conversion. I will have something next week for you.  Our understanding of the TTT adaption request: 
Turn the Managing Bias in the Workplace for Leaders live facilitation portion into a dynamic e-modules
Combination microlearnings, videos
Will have competency quizzes to verify learning
Supported by the discussion toolkit (revamped to support content) for learners to use in real-time
Option of a live Q&A (quarterly or biannual LCW staffed event) to support learner question/problem solving 
 
Thank you 
Tahitia
 
 
 
------------------------------------------------------
Tahitia Timmons
(she/her/hers)
Senior Consultant
LCW 
100 S Saunders Rd, Suite 150
Lake Forest, IL 60045

From:
 Rubano, Karen <
Karen.Rubano@sbdinc.com
> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, August 10, 2022 1:42 PM
To:
 Tahitia Timmons <
t.timmons@lcwmail.com
>; Kelly Salek <
k.salek@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Hello from Stanley Black & Decker - Unconscious Bias
 
Hi Tahitia and Kelly!  I hope all is well and you are surviving multiple heat waves throughout the US 
😊
 
Next week, a small group of SBD DEI and L&D practitioners are starting to discuss how to influence UB awareness across the enterprise.  All agree we have reached the LCW MUBW shelf-life, and all agree we must find a way to deliver a sustainable drip of content to our SBD employees.  Although Managers continue to be a primary target audience, we must think beyond Managers to our independent contributors and our manufacturing population.  All said, I have 3 questions:
 
Is LCW updating the 30 minute UB e-learning introduction that currently all new SBD hires experience? 
The only general UB offer I see on the recent document Tahitia sent me (current micro-learnings, elearnings, workshops) is pictured below.  Many of the research and data dates are quite old – some over 10 years old, many 2014-2017.  Is this product being updated?
I know you are working on a pilot proposal for us to take a look at – how is progress?
 
There is no doubt we have interest in building an UB experience.  LinkedIn learning will be one aspect but we need more.  We need to be cost conscious and yet we need to deliver – a fine balance.  TY for any info you can provide!
 
Karen
 
 
Karen Rubano  
 
Global Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Center of Excellence
Stanley Black & Decker
860-304-1228

 Andrea Wicks Bowles <
a.wicksbowles@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Upcoming Webinars - HRCI/SHRM Credit and Complimentary Admission!
 
From Day One is hosting complimentary webinars all summer long and we think they’ll be of interest to you or your colleagues. All events listed are eligible for credit from SHRM and HRCI. 
Return to Work Best Practices
Tuesday, August 16, 2:00-3:00 pm ET
Eligible for 1 credit from SHRM and HRCI
Tis the season for back-to-school, but what about returning to work for parents? As retention rates remain unstable, HR leaders need to focus on ways to keep their workforce engaged. In this session, leaders will discuss best practices for Return to Work and leave programming. From welcoming a new parent back from parental leave to welcoming your workforce back to the office, you’ll learn proven ways to keep employees engaged, balanced and productive while preventing burnout.
Register here
.
Focusing Employee Coaching to Ensure the Best Results
Thursday, August 25, 2:00-3:00 pm ET
Eligible for 1 credit from SHRM and HRCI
Companies are quickly finding out what coaches have always known: coaching is a powerful tool for well-being and development that should be made available to all employees. Yet for best effects, employers need to make sure they define it thoughtfully and differentiate it from other important practices, including mentoring, training, and therapy. What is the essence of the collaborative relationship between the coach and the employee? How can the relationship keep focused on building momentum and moving forward? What ensures that the coaching is self-directed by the employee, rather than following a set curriculum? When does coaching have the most impact?
Register here
.
The New Role of the Office in an Era of Hybrid Work
Tuesday, August 30, 2:00-3:00 pm ET
Eligible for 1 credit from SHRM and HRCI
Given that most employees now prefer a mix of remote and office work, employers need to be more intentional about giving workers genuine, compelling reasons to show up in person. What kind of innovations is this inspiring in terms of workplace design, staff organization, space utilization, meeting styles, special events, and new technologies? How has this challenge improved office life and culture for the better?
Register here
.
Mastering Your Tech-enabled Employee Experience
Thursday, September 1, 2:00-3:00 pm ET
Eligible for 1 credit from SHRM and HRCI
The number one reason employees changed jobs during the pandemic was for better work flexibility. Providing an employee experience of connection and belonging is crucial for engagement and retention, but business leaders remain uncertain how to achieve this with the tools and processes available. The latest Achievers Workforce Institute research offers guidance into how organizations can use the right technology to create a culture of connection and belonging. 
Register here
.
Creating New Pathways of Access to Economic Opportunity and Inclusion
Thursday, September 8, 2:00-3:00 pm ET
Eligible for 1 credit from SHRM and HRCI
With income and wealth inequality worse in the U.S. than most other developed countries, innovative cross-sector partnerships are taking new approaches to entrepreneurship, fellowships, internships and other pathways that are opening doors to talent from historically marginalized or underrepresented communities. What are some of the most effective and scalable efforts underway now–and how can these collaborations be replicated by employers and nonprofits in search of more diverse workforces?
Register here
.
Best,
Lydia Samson (she/her)
From Day One 
lydia@fromdayone.co
If you wish to unsubscribe from our newsletter, click 
here

subject: RE: Hello from Stanley Black & Decker - Unconscious Bias
body:
Hi Karen, 
In answer to your questions: 
#1&2. The e-learning UB offering is currently being revised and refreshed. Unfortunately, what we currently are showing is the previous version and does not showcase the new look and or the updated content. However, I can share some preview slides of another course to help give you a feel for what the new training will look like. 
#3. Yes, we are working on that proposal for your train-the-trainer. I am attaching the original TTT LCW schedule for that program so you have something as a reference for our conversion. I will have something next week for you.  Our understanding of the TTT adaption request: 
Turn the Managing Bias in the Workplace for Leaders live facilitation portion into a dynamic e-modules
Combination microlearnings, videos
Will have competency quizzes to verify learning
Supported by the discussion toolkit (revamped to support content) for learners to use in real-time
Option of a live Q&A (quarterly or biannual LCW staffed event) to support learner question/problem solving 
 
Thank you 
Tahitia

 Rubano, Karen <Karen.Rubano@sbdinc.com> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, August 10, 2022 1:42 PM
To:
 Tahitia Timmons <t.timmons@lcwmail.com>; Kelly Salek <k.salek@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Hello from Stanley Black & Decker - Unconscious Bias
 
Hi Tahitia and Kelly!  I hope all is well and you are surviving multiple heat waves throughout the US 
😊
 
Next week, a small group of SBD DEI and L&D practitioners are starting to discuss how to influence UB awareness across the enterprise.  All agree we have reached the LCW MUBW shelf-life, and all agree we must find a way to deliver a sustainable drip of content to our SBD employees.  Although Managers continue to be a primary target audience, we must think beyond Managers to our independent contributors and our manufacturing population.  All said, I have 3 questions:
 
Is LCW updating the 30 minute UB e-learning introduction that currently all new SBD hires experience? 
The only general UB offer I see on the recent document Tahitia sent me (current micro-learnings, elearnings, workshops) is pictured below.  Many of the research and data dates are quite old – some over 10 years old, many 2014-2017.  Is this product being updated?
I know you are working on a pilot proposal for us to take a look at – how is progress?
 
There is no doubt we have interest in building an UB experience.  LinkedIn learning will be one aspect but we need more.  We need to be cost conscious and yet we need to deliver – a fine balance.  TY for any info you can provide!
 
Karen
 
 
Karen Rubano

Hi Nassise, 
I am helping with IMUB – however, the request was to review for outdated/ableist/violence enabling/ language, regulatory concerns, and see if newer evidence existed for some of the evidence in the course.  After talking with Kelly, I will be taking a relook at the “what would you do section”  and microinequities slides to see how we can add selectable slides for additional areas. This may or may not meet your request.  I am currently not involved with the Conscious Inclusion work but have a list of priority e-learnings to look at similar to the IMUB request. 
I do not anticipate being able to complete any additional projects in my final days here at LCW. I am only here 2 days next week and prioritizing existing client and internal requests along with client handoffs. 
That said I am always open to hearing what an external proposal for contract work with LCW would look like. 
Thank you  
Tahitia

Hello, 
Please join me July 28
th
 , with my colleague Ada Vargas, as we prepare for Hispanic Heritage Month. 
We will provide a special preview of two LCWs educational offerings: Understanding the Latinx Experience in America and Spotlight on the Latinx Community. You can use the registration link to 
reserve up to 3 seats
 and don’t forget to schedule time with me so we can bring one of these offerings to your organization. 
See you on the 28
th
!
Tahitia Timmons
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Join us for an LCW client event: 
Preparing for Hispanic Heritage Month
 
Reserve your seat for this session now!
 
 
You've been selected by an LCW staff member for an exclusive invite to this LCW client event!
 
Throughout this one-hour event, we'll explore key experiences that tend to impact your Latinx colleagues, and share proven strategies for building cultural competence for stronger connections with the Latinx community... not only in time for Hispanic Heritage Month, but all-year-long. 
This unique event allows participants to experience LCW training activities and come together for meaningful discussion. Together we will: 
Gain insight into the depth and rich history of the Latinx community
Examine some experiences that tend to shape the identity of many who identify as members of this culture
Discuss strategies for making the Latinx community feel seen, valued, and respected all-year-long
This session is only available by invite! Use the registration link provided in this email and 
reserve up to 3 seats
 for your organization.
Make sure to reserve your seat now; seats for this session are available on a first-come basis!

Hello, 
Please join me July 28
th
 , with my colleague Ada Vargas, as we prepare for Hispanic Heritage Month. 
We will provide a special preview of two LCWs educational offerings: Understanding the Latinx Experience in America and Spotlight on the Latinx Community. You can use the registration link to 
reserve up to 3 seats
 and don’t forget to schedule time with me so we can bring one of these offerings to your organization. 
See you on the 28
th
!
Tahitia Timmons
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Join us for an LCW client event: 
Preparing for Hispanic Heritage Month
 
Reserve your seat for this session now!
 
 
You've been selected by an LCW staff member for an exclusive invite to this LCW client event!
 
Throughout this one-hour event, we'll explore key experiences that tend to impact your Latinx colleagues, and share proven strategies for building cultural competence for stronger connections with the Latinx community... not only in time for Hispanic Heritage Month, but all-year-long. 
This unique event allows participants to experience LCW training activities and come together for meaningful discussion. Together we will: 
Gain insight into the depth and rich history of the Latinx community
Examine some experiences that tend to shape the identity of many who identify as members of this culture
Discuss strategies for making the Latinx community feel seen, valued, and respected all-year-long
This session is only available by invite! Use the registration link provided in this email and 
reserve up to 3 seats
 for your organization.
Make sure to reserve your seat now; seats for this session are available on a first-come basis! 
 
 
Copyright © 2022 Language & Culture Worldwide, LLC, All rights reserved.
Our mailing address is:
100 S Saunders Rd, Suite 150
Lake Forest, IL 60045

Hello, 
Please join me July 28
th
 , with my colleague Ada Vargas, as we prepare for Hispanic Heritage Month. 
We will provide a special preview of two LCWs educational offerings: Understanding the Latinx Experience in America and Spotlight on the Latinx Community. You can use the registration link to 
reserve up to 3 seats
 and don’t forget to schedule time with me so we can bring one of these offerings to your organization. 
See you on the 28
th
!
Tahitia Timmons
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Join us for an LCW client event: 
Preparing for Hispanic Heritage Month
 
Reserve your seat for this session now!
 
 
You've been selected by an LCW staff member for an exclusive invite to this LCW client event!
 
Throughout this one-hour event, we'll explore key experiences that tend to impact your Latinx colleagues, and share proven strategies for building cultural competence for stronger connections with the Latinx community... not only in time for Hispanic Heritage Month, but all-year-long. 
This unique event allows participants to experience LCW training activities and come together for meaningful discussion. Together we will: 
Gain insight into the depth and rich history of the Latinx community
Examine some experiences that tend to shape the identity of many who identify as members of this culture
Discuss strategies for making the Latinx community feel seen, valued, and respected all-year-long
This session is only available by invite! Use the registration link provided in this email and 
reserve up to 3 seats
 for your organization.
Make sure to reserve your seat now; seats for this session are available on a first-come basis!

Subject:
 RE: Request: Content Development for BSC IMUB E-learning 
 
Hi Nassise, 
I am helping with IMUB – however, the request was to review for outdated/ableist/violence enabling/ language, regulatory concerns, and see if newer evidence existed for some of the evidence in the course.  After talking with Kelly, I will be taking a relook at the “what would you do section”  and microinequities slides to see how we can add selectable slides for additional areas. This may or may not meet your request.  I am currently not involved with the Conscious Inclusion work but have a list of priority e-learnings to look at similar to the IMUB request. 
I do not anticipate being able to complete any additional projects in my final days here at LCW. I am only here 2 days next week and prioritizing existing client and internal requests along with client handoffs. 
That said I am always open to hearing what an external proposal for contract work with LCW would look like. 
Thank you  
Tahitia

This message came from outside your organization. Use caution when opening. 
ZjQcmQRYFpfptBannerEnd
Hi Jason, 
Great talk the other day, it helped clarify what needs to be done for the Latinx program. Based on the materials that Arlene shared, I have 3 suggested LCW options in the attached PDF. 
Option 1 provides the deepest cultural dive into the Latinx Community – with a 4-hour session with two facilitators – I advise breaking this into two sessions (Part 1 & 2)
Option 2 - offers a 1-hour Spotlight view on the Latinx Community which of course can be tailored to reflect what is most important to communicate to Danaher.
Option 3 -LCW works with the existing content but refreshes it, it would also include a Latinx Panel session and does not include the Building Executive Presence Session or the Power of Allyship session. 
 
Personally,  I lean towards option two as it gives the most education and learning content (something you mentioned in our meeting) and reinforces learning in a new way. In addition,  I think the Building an Executive presence might have the potential to replace not just your Latinx Panel session but even the Black Executive Panel session since the Executive group for BAES and LAES consist of almost the same people. 
Please note the Panel session quotes do not include the cost of the external speaker. 
I know you wanted to review the decks, however, our practice is not to share decks, but to provide a guided walkthrough as this allows for Q&A.  
 
Regarding additional LCW content, at the end of the pdf, you will find two pages on our mini-workshops (these range in cost from $4,500 -$9,000 depending on length and number of presenters) and two pages on our Building a Culture of Inclusion course. We can always do a content walkthrough if something sparks with you. 
Would you like to set up some type of meeting cadence as we work out the details of this project?
 I think it would be helpful to have some type of check-in so we can keep everything on track. 
 
Looking forward to knowing which option best meets your needs. 
Best, 
Tahitia
 
------------------------------------------------------

Subject:
 Our call today
 
Hi team, 
 
Adrianne is in Cannes this week, and I only have a few items on my list, so I was thinking we could share updates via email this week.  
 
LMK if that works for you, or if there was something specific you wanted to discuss today. 
 
In the meantime, below is what I have on my radar. 
Focus Groups
EMEA
: Confirmed and on the calendar for 7/6.
APAC:
 Waiting to hear back from the facilitator about additional times for July. 
US API:
 Waiting to hear back from the facilitator. At this point Thursday, 7/7: 11am-12pm CT is probably the best option so let me know if I should look at the second/third weeks of July too. 
1:1 Stakeholder Interviews
Scheduling
: LCW working on time blocks. I also have a meeting with Lisa Moehlenkamp tomorrow to give her a heads up that we’re starting to schedule. 
Questions:
 FH/LCW to finalize questions. 
I know your team is working on those based on our conversation last week. 
To Adrianne’s point on the call, we think there are three “themes” to these conversations: Personal commitment, accountability (for themselves and others) and I also think hearing their perspective on existing barriers or challenges that make it harder for them or their teams to make inclusion a priority, such as business demands from the firm. 
Also, if there are any other themes that have emerged from the focus groups that we want to ask about, such as the point that Dan brought up about utilization, that is great too. 
I also gave this some thought so sharing some ideas below. 
What personal goals/commitments have you made as it relates to DE&I? Can you share an example of actions that have supported those commitments?
As a leader, how are you holding yourself accountable? How do you hold other leaders and managers on your team accountable?
Where does DE&I fit in with your other business priorities?
Would love thoughts on this one. I think it’s easy to say that DE&I is a priority but actually practicing that is more difficult. I think our focus on utilization is a great example. So I want to ask a question that digs into what DE&I being a priority looks like 
in action
 for these leaders beyond just  “voicing support.” 
From the GM deck: Which processes or policies limit or enhance a culture of inclusion and sense of belonging at FleishmanHillard? What is working or not working?
DE&I Certification Exploratory Conversation: Confirmed for 6/30
 
LMK if there is anything I missed. 
 
Thanks!
Rachel

Hi Edward, 
Great discussion today!
Attached is a proposed quote which can always be modified. I included the facilitated learnings we discussed and three micro learnings with pricing. As I mentioned they are moving away from the current eLearning model toward an LMS (soft launch end of Q4). I have these at 25 users and 6 months (they are not doing 12 months).  There were also price increases since the list you shared and I cannot override them BUT I was able to still have the 25% show up, however that is contingent on the prepay and 4+ and will no longer be available moving forward
I am also enclosing a link to a zip folder with pdfs of the facilitated titles we discussed. 
That is available here 
https://www.dropbox.com/l/AACk8tB0EdaazCqPPmltk1-8gcXTHuk8WVs

Hopefully this will assist you when you meet with the group on Monday. 
Thanks and have a great weekend!
 
Tahitia

Hello, 
Please join me July 28
th
 , with my colleague Ada Vargas, as we prepare for Hispanic Heritage Month. 
We will provide a special preview of two LCWs educational offerings: Understanding the Latinx Experience in America and Spotlight on the Latinx Community. You can use the registration link to 
reserve up to 3 seats
 and don’t forget to schedule time with me so we can bring one of these offerings to your organization. 
See you on the 28
th
!
Tahitia Timmons
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Join us for an LCW client event: 
Preparing for Hispanic Heritage Month
 
Reserve your seat for this session now!
 
 
You've been selected by an LCW staff member for an exclusive invite to this LCW client event!
 
Throughout this one-hour event, we'll explore key experiences that tend to impact your Latinx colleagues, and share proven strategies for building cultural competence for stronger connections with the Latinx community... not only in time for Hispanic Heritage Month, but all-year-long. 
This unique event allows participants to experience LCW training activities and come together for meaningful discussion. Together we will: 
Gain insight into the depth and rich history of the Latinx community
Examine some experiences that tend to shape the identity of many who identify as members of this culture
Discuss strategies for making the Latinx community feel seen, valued, and respected all-year-long
This session is only available by invite! Use the registration link provided in this email and 
reserve up to 3 seats
 for your organization.
Make sure to reserve your seat now; seats for this session are available on a first-come basis!

From:

Sent:
 Wednesday, August 10, 2022 1:57 PM
To:
 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 508 Compliance 
 
Hi Emani, 
Here is that info around 508 compliance as promised, There are different levels of compliance too so it depends on what the group is aiming for. 508 compliance with AAA is often the goal and it applies to any entity that does or wants to do business with a federal agency, meaning it does not apply to private websites. . That said 508 compliance with AA or AAA is often the goal for all industries since it allows you to be a third-party vendor to organizations that require it.

Hello, 
Please join me July 28
th
 , with my colleague Ada Vargas, as we prepare for Hispanic Heritage Month. 
We will provide a special preview of two LCWs educational offerings: Understanding the Latinx Experience in America and Spotlight on the Latinx Community. You can use the registration link to 
reserve up to 3 seats
 and don’t forget to schedule time with me so we can bring one of these offerings to your organization. 
See you on the 28
th
!
Tahitia Timmons
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Join us for an LCW client event: 
Preparing for Hispanic Heritage Month
 
Reserve your seat for this session now!
 
 
You've been selected by an LCW staff member for an exclusive invite to this LCW client event!
 
Throughout this one-hour event, we'll explore key experiences that tend to impact your Latinx colleagues, and share proven strategies for building cultural competence for stronger connections with the Latinx community... not only in time for Hispanic Heritage Month, but all-year-long. 
This unique event allows participants to experience LCW training activities and come together for meaningful discussion. Together we will: 
Gain insight into the depth and rich history of the Latinx community
Examine some experiences that tend to shape the identity of many who identify as members of this culture
Discuss strategies for making the Latinx community feel seen, valued, and respected all-year-long
This session is only available by invite! Use the registration link provided in this email and 
reserve up to 3 seats
 for your organization.
Make sure to reserve your seat now; seats for this session are available on a first-come basis!

subject: Hello from Stanley Black & Decker - Unconscious Bias
body:
Hi Tahitia and Kelly!  I hope all is well and you are surviving multiple heat waves throughout the US 
😊
 
Next week, a small group of SBD DEI and L&D practitioners are starting to discuss how to influence UB awareness across the enterprise.  All agree we have reached the LCW MUBW shelf-life, and all agree we must find a way to deliver a sustainable drip of content to our SBD employees.  Although Managers continue to be a primary target audience, we must think beyond Managers to our independent contributors and our manufacturing population.  All said, I have 3 questions:
 
Is LCW updating the 30 minute UB e-learning introduction that currently all new SBD hires experience? 
The only general UB offer I see on the recent document Tahitia sent me (current micro-learnings, elearnings, workshops) is pictured below.  Many of the research and data dates are quite old – some over 10 years old, many 2014-2017.  Is this product being updated?
I know you are working on a pilot proposal for us to take a look at – how is progress?
 
There is no doubt we have interest in building an UB experience.  LinkedIn learning will be one aspect but we need more.  We need to be cost conscious and yet we need to deliver – a fine balance.  TY for any info you can provide!
 
Karen
 
 
Karen Rubano  
 
Global Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Center of Excellence
Stanley Black & Decker
860-304-1228
 
www.stanleyblackanddecker.com
https://www.stanleyblackanddecker.com/careers/working-here
https://www.stanleyblackanddecker.com/who-we-are/our-culture

Subject:
 RE: Inclusion Learning Journeys.pptx
 
Hi Monica,
 
I shared some of this feedback with Chuck, so apologies for the redundancies if you’ve heard some this already.
 
Overall
This is in a much better place than the previous iteration! Love the colors, the buckets, the emerging sense of the journey, the foregrounding of inclusive leadership
I am evaluating these through the lens of how I will talk to a client about these journeys, especially in the context of a 30-45-minute meeting, where clients want to know
What are the skills their leaders need (i.e., the 4 inclusive leader competencies)
What are the content areas they need to engage (e.g., unconscious bias, microaggressions, inclusion)
I have mocked up a few slides (attached) to place between the SCI and the detailed slides that more succinctly communicate what we are trying to do—many of the more detailed slides are great as backup/appendix slides, as well for upskilling our consultants, but too much information for our clients to digest at first 
Similarly, the hierarchy-specific journeys are great and useful for similar reasons, but too much information for clients until we have alignment and buy-in on the overall journey
 
Course-specific
I think the most urgent to-do here is picking out 2-3 themes for each Inclusive leadership competency (e.g., “Unconscious Bias” and “Microaggressions” for #1 Awareness and Knowledge)
Specifically, the content areas look mostly good to me—I think the blurriest line is between #3 and #4, and I’m wondering if #4 is where we can place something that addresses “Psychological Safety,” or other areas where we know our clients are moving toward but that where we haven’t developed content quite yet. I, personally, am comfortable socializing these themes without a completed course, since most of our clients aren’t anywhere neat that. If it becomes a need/request, we can build it. But we should at least show that we are moving toward something new. 
 
Happy to answer any questions and/or voice over the mock slides I made.
 
Thanks,
Dan

Hello folks!
Attached is an updated effort to incorporate feedback on what people liked/didn’t like in the “UTBE” Learning Journey. Of course – eventually a gorgeous formatting job from Keri/Kelly will also be needed. 
😊
 
But for now… as a first step…
 
Since each of you has expressed interest in seeing what journey maps aligned to the SCI model and Inclusive Leadership might look like–I’d love your thoughts on the attached. It is by no means PRETTY (at all) – but note I focused on:
color-coding the Inclusive Leadership Competency Framework to align with the already agreed upon graphic for the “Sustainable Culture of Inclusion Model”
creating distinct inclusive leadership learning journeys for 3 groups: 
All audiences including individual contributors 
Senior leaders
Middle managers
 
Tahitia, Andrea, Sarah, Dan and Tamara
 – I’d love you to see if you like the courses listed under each, and what you might change.
 
Chuck, Alisa, Kell, Nicole and Melissa
 – I’d welcome your thoughts on the overall concepts here, knowing that I’ve tried to capture my expertise and experience for you in a transferrable way.
 
If we are headed in the right direction – I will format the “Bias Learning Journeys” attached. For now I’ve just documented the courses, trying to minimize (but not necessarily completely eliminate) redundancy with the Inclusive Leadership Journeys so that you can sell both to a given client. 
 
I’ll set up time to talk through these with some of you next week. 
 
 
Thank you 
😊
M

subject: RE: Our call today
body:
Hello Rachel,
 
Thanks so much for your patience. I’d suggest we reconvene on Thursday, September 1
st
. With regard to the read out date, we may want to start looking for dates mid September.
 
And apologies for missing the Monday deadline for your APAC call, I’m pulling together some of those themes for you now. Perhaps you can share them with the APCA folks in another communication.
 
Let me know if there is anything else you need.
 
Tamara
 
From:
 Rachel Coleman (FleishmanHillard) <Rachel.Coleman@fleishman.com> 
Sent:
 Thursday, August 4, 2022 12:07 PM
To:
 Tamara Thorpe <t.thorpe@lcwmail.com>; Daniel Gough <d.gough@lcwmail.com>; Vince Bongiovanni <v.bongiovanni@lcwmail.com>; Tahitia Timmons <t.timmons@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Adrianne Smith (FleishmanHillard) <adrianne.smith@fleishman.com>
Subject:
 RE: Our call today
 
Hi Tamara, 
 
We’re good with holding off on the weekly meetings for a few weeks. Do you have a date in mind that you’d like to regroup? Or should we circle back on that once we have the last two stakeholder interviews scheduled? Also, Adrianne and I talked about the initial readout, and that will likely be Adrianne, Lisa, J.J. and myself. I know we still have some time, but let us know when we should start looking at dates for that. There might be one or two other groups that we want to review the findings, but we can decide on that as we get closer.

Subject:
 Our call today
 
Hi team, 
 
Adrianne is in Cannes this week, and I only have a few items on my list, so I was thinking we could share updates via email this week.  
 
LMK if that works for you, or if there was something specific you wanted to discuss today. 
 
In the meantime, below is what I have on my radar. 
Focus Groups
EMEA
: Confirmed and on the calendar for 7/6.
APAC:
 Waiting to hear back from the facilitator about additional times for July. 
US API:
 Waiting to hear back from the facilitator. At this point Thursday, 7/7: 11am-12pm CT is probably the best option so let me know if I should look at the second/third weeks of July too. 
1:1 Stakeholder Interviews
Scheduling
: LCW working on time blocks. I also have a meeting with Lisa Moehlenkamp tomorrow to give her a heads up that we’re starting to schedule. 
Questions:
 FH/LCW to finalize questions. 
I know your team is working on those based on our conversation last week. 
To Adrianne’s point on the call, we think there are three “themes” to these conversations: Personal commitment, accountability (for themselves and others) and I also think hearing their perspective on existing barriers or challenges that make it harder for them or their teams to make inclusion a priority, such as business demands from the firm. 
Also, if there are any other themes that have emerged from the focus groups that we want to ask about, such as the point that Dan brought up about utilization, that is great too. 
I also gave this some thought so sharing some ideas below. 
What personal goals/commitments have you made as it relates to DE&I? Can you share an example of actions that have supported those commitments?
As a leader, how are you holding yourself accountable? How do you hold other leaders and managers on your team accountable?
Where does DE&I fit in with your other business priorities?
Would love thoughts on this one. I think it’s easy to say that DE&I is a priority but actually practicing that is more difficult. I think our focus on utilization is a great example. So I want to ask a question that digs into what DE&I being a priority looks like 
in action
 for these leaders beyond just  “voicing support.” 
From the GM deck: Which processes or policies limit or enhance a culture of inclusion and sense of belonging at FleishmanHillard? What is working or not working?
DE&I Certification Exploratory Conversation: Confirmed for 6/30
 
LMK if there is anything I missed. 
 
Thanks!
Rachel

This might be a good time to share the Conscious Inclusion course (see attached) to them and see if that content is something they might like (all topics they mention below). We are just about ready to build that one once we get the content finalized…If they bite and we sell this one, I can get the designers to start ASAP.

Let’s talk…I am free in the AM. Sorry about the late response.

Hi Kelly,
 
See the below ask from BSC.
 
For context: They bought IMUB in 2018. They have it in several languages. They would like to “refresh” (customize!) the content as per the specs below, and we need a budget estimate TODAY.
 
Can you help provide me with a number, a minimum and maximum as Meg requests?
 
A big question I have is whether we would ask them to pay for a new license, or just charge them for making the changes.
 
Let me know your thoughts. 
 
Thank you!
Sarah
 
 
 
From:
 Grow, Meg (they/them/theirs) <
Meg.Grow@bsci.com
> 
Sent:
 Monday, August 8, 2022 11:53 PM
To:
 Sarah Nodarse <
s.nodarse@lcwmail.com
>; Emani Richmond <
e.richmond@lcwmail.com
>; Tamara Thorpe <
t.thorpe@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 RE: Fire drill ask
 
Apparently noon turns into midnight? Here’s what I’ve gathered. We’re in the throes of budgeting, so truly need a directional estimate ASAP. The Maximum is what we’ll likely ask for, and the Minimum is what Wendy will fight to keep.
BSC would like to update the online learning module in order to 1) refresh content and broaden to reflect current biases (e.g. remote worker, neurodiverse), 2) resolve continued issues related to completion documentation, and 3) improve the overall learner experience. 
Minimum Requirements
Replace images of South Asian individuals with a less caricature/stylized look, specifically the trio flashing “peace” signs and the woman in What Would You Do
Speak to remote worker and neurodiversity at least once each. Potential sections include 
Self-Assess
What Would You Do 
Inclusive Behaviors 
Replace optical illusion section with accessible metaphor
Update dated stock images (e.g., woman on Too young, too old)
Updates made to all language versions 
Maximum Requirements
In addition to the above stated Minimum Requirements,
Resolve issues related to documentation of completion. Best practice: Replace navigation-based completion metric with 5 question quiz
Improve digital accessibility (e.g., allow keyboard navigation, especially interactive slides like About This Course) – aim for WCAG Lvl A
Remove “canned reactions” from audio track (e.g., laughter from Microinequities “apple” slide & cheering from Congratulations)
Remove or replace the high-pitched chime used in the What Would You Do section

Sarah

body:
Thanks all. I like where we’re headed. I connected with Dan to create this updated “themes” slide to address his comments in yellow. Any tweaks are welcome. (see below). Other than that – I’m officially turning this over to Kelly to take the lead from here. Thanks team!
 
 
From:
 Daniel Gough <d.gough@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, August 9, 2022 3:15 PM
To:
 Chuck Adams <c.adams@lcwmail.com>; Monica Marcel <m.marcel@lcwmail.com>; Alisa Kolodizner <a.kolodizner@lcwmail.com>; Kelly Salek <k.salek@lcwmail.com>; Tahitia Timmons <t.timmons@lcwmail.com>; Andrea Wicks Bowles <a.wicksbowles@lcwmail.com>; Sarah Nodarse <s.nodarse@lcwmail.com>; Tamara Thorpe <t.thorpe@lcwmail.com>; Melissa Neu <m.neu@lcwmail.com>; Nicole Barile <n.barile@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Inclusion Learning Journeys.pptx
 
Hi Monica,
 
I shared some of this feedback with Chuck, so apologies for the redundancies if you’ve heard some this already.
 
Overall
This is in a much better place than the previous iteration! Love the colors, the buckets, the emerging sense of the journey, the foregrounding of inclusive leadership
I am evaluating these through the lens of how I will talk to a client about these journeys, especially in the context of a 30-45-minute meeting, where clients want to know
What are the skills their leaders need (i.e., the 4 inclusive leader competencies)
What are the content areas they need to engage (e.g., unconscious bias, microaggressions, inclusion)
I have mocked up a few slides (attached) to place between the SCI and the detailed slides that more succinctly communicate what we are trying to do—many of the more detailed slides are great as backup/appendix slides, as well for upskilling our consultants, but too much information for our clients to digest at first 
Similarly, the hierarchy-specific journeys are great and useful for similar reasons, but too much information for clients until we have alignment and buy-in on the overall journey
 
Course-specific
I think the most urgent to-do here is picking out 2-3 themes for each Inclusive leadership competency (e.g., “Unconscious Bias” and “Microaggressions” for #1 Awareness and Knowledge)
Specifically, the content areas look mostly good to me—I think the blurriest line is between #3 and #4, and I’m wondering if #4 is where we can place something that addresses “Psychological Safety,” or other areas where we know our clients are moving toward but that where we haven’t developed content quite yet. I, personally, am comfortable socializing these themes without a completed course, since most of our clients aren’t anywhere neat that. If it becomes a need/request, we can build it. But we should at least show that we are moving toward something new. 
 
Happy to answer any questions and/or voice over the mock slides I made.
 
Thanks,
Dan

Hello folks!
Attached is an updated effort to incorporate feedback on what people liked/didn’t like in the “UTBE” Learning Journey. Of course – eventually a gorgeous formatting job from Keri/Kelly will also be needed. 
😊
 
But for now… as a first step…
 
Since each of you has expressed interest in seeing what journey maps aligned to the SCI model and Inclusive Leadership might look like–I’d love your thoughts on the attached. It is by no means PRETTY (at all) – but note I focused on:
color-coding the Inclusive Leadership Competency Framework to align with the already agreed upon graphic for the “Sustainable Culture of Inclusion Model”
creating distinct inclusive leadership learning journeys for 3 groups: 
All audiences including individual contributors 
Senior leaders
Middle managers
 
Tahitia, Andrea, Sarah, Dan and Tamara
 – I’d love you to see if you like the courses listed under each, and what you might change.
 
Chuck, Alisa, Kell, Nicole and Melissa
 – I’d welcome your thoughts on the overall concepts here, knowing that I’ve tried to capture my expertise and experience for you in a transferrable way.
 
If we are headed in the right direction – I will format the “Bias Learning Journeys” attached. For now I’ve just documented the courses, trying to minimize (but not necessarily completely eliminate) redundancy with the Inclusive Leadership Journeys so that you can sell both to a given client. 
 
I’ll set up time to talk through these with some of you next week. 
 
 
Thank you 
😊
M

subject: Accepted: [Internal] Weekly Carta Touchbase
body:
Hi Emani, 
I would probably clarify with Carta what their goal is with the presentation. My perhaps false thoughts: they were trying to discuss women in tech and then bias around age and technology. I am not sure that if that is the goal those facilitator choices would be ideal. I thought they were leaning towards a more Girls who code and/or we hire old people, or women and aging thing.  But clarify with them, if they also do not need two facilitators you could spend that on an external expert in the tech field OR try and get Kelly to do it as a woman in tech with experience in the field. 
Thanks
Tahitia

Hello, 
Please join me July 28
th
 , with my colleague Ada Vargas, as we prepare for Hispanic Heritage Month. 
We will provide a special preview of two LCWs educational offerings: Understanding the Latinx Experience in America and Spotlight on the Latinx Community. You can use the registration link to 
reserve up to 3 seats
 and don’t forget to schedule time with me so we can bring one of these offerings to your organization. 
See you on the 28
th
!
Tahitia Timmons
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Join us for an LCW client event: 
Preparing for Hispanic Heritage Month
 
Reserve your seat for this session now!
 
 
You've been selected by an LCW staff member for an exclusive invite to this LCW client event!
 
Throughout this one-hour event, we'll explore key experiences that tend to impact your Latinx colleagues, and share proven strategies for building cultural competence for stronger connections with the Latinx community... not only in time for Hispanic Heritage Month, but all-year-long. 
This unique event allows participants to experience LCW training activities and come together for meaningful discussion. Together we will: 
Gain insight into the depth and rich history of the Latinx community
Examine some experiences that tend to shape the identity of many who identify as members of this culture
Discuss strategies for making the Latinx community feel seen, valued, and respected all-year-long
This session is only available by invite! Use the registration link provided in this email and 
reserve up to 3 seats
 for your organization.
Make sure to reserve your seat now; seats for this session are available on a first-come basis! 
 
 
Copyright © 2022 Language & Culture Worldwide, LLC, All rights reserved.
Our mailing address is:
100 S Saunders Rd, Suite 150
Lake Forest, IL 60045

to: c.adams@lcwmail.com, m.marcel@lcwmail.com, a.kolodizner@lcwmail.com, k.salek@lcwmail.com, t.timmons@lcwmail.com, a.wicksbowles@lcwmail.com, s.nodarse@lcwmail.com, t.thorpe@lcwmail.com, m.neu@lcwmail.com, n.barile@lcwmail.com
subject: RE: Inclusion Learning Journeys.pptx
body:
Hi Monica,
 
I shared some of this feedback with Chuck, so apologies for the redundancies if you’ve heard some this already.
 
Overall
This is in a much better place than the previous iteration! Love the colors, the buckets, the emerging sense of the journey, the foregrounding of inclusive leadership
I am evaluating these through the lens of how I will talk to a client about these journeys, especially in the context of a 30-45-minute meeting, where clients want to know
What are the skills their leaders need (i.e., the 4 inclusive leader competencies)
What are the content areas they need to engage (e.g., unconscious bias, microaggressions, inclusion)
I have mocked up a few slides (attached) to place between the SCI and the detailed slides that more succinctly communicate what we are trying to do—many of the more detailed slides are great as backup/appendix slides, as well for upskilling our consultants, but too much information for our clients to digest at first 
Similarly, the hierarchy-specific journeys are great and useful for similar reasons, but too much information for clients until we have alignment and buy-in on the overall journey
 
Course-specific
I think the most urgent to-do here is picking out 2-3 themes for each Inclusive leadership competency (e.g., “Unconscious Bias” and “Microaggressions” for #1 Awareness and Knowledge)
Specifically, the content areas look mostly good to me—I think the blurriest line is between #3 and #4, and I’m wondering if #4 is where we can place something that addresses “Psychological Safety,” or other areas where we know our clients are moving toward but that where we haven’t developed content quite yet. I, personally, am comfortable socializing these themes without a completed course, since most of our clients aren’t anywhere neat that. If it becomes a need/request, we can build it. But we should at least show that we are moving toward something new. 
 
Happy to answer any questions and/or voice over the mock slides I made.
 
Thanks,
Dan
 
 
Daniel Gough, PhD
(he, him, his)
Principal Consultant
LCW
100 S Saunders Rd, Suite 150
Lake Forest, IL 60045
 
Office +1 773 938 4170
Mobile +1 312 285 9689

Hello folks!
Attached is an updated effort to incorporate feedback on what people liked/didn’t like in the “UTBE” Learning Journey. Of course – eventually a gorgeous formatting job from Keri/Kelly will also be needed. 
😊
 
But for now… as a first step…
 
Since each of you has expressed interest in seeing what journey maps aligned to the SCI model and Inclusive Leadership might look like–I’d love your thoughts on the attached. It is by no means PRETTY (at all) – but note I focused on:
color-coding the Inclusive Leadership Competency Framework to align with the already agreed upon graphic for the “Sustainable Culture of Inclusion Model”
creating distinct inclusive leadership learning journeys for 3 groups: 
All audiences including individual contributors 
Senior leaders
Middle managers
 
Tahitia, Andrea, Sarah, Dan and Tamara
 – I’d love you to see if you like the courses listed under each, and what you might change.
 
Chuck, Alisa, Kell, Nicole and Melissa
 – I’d welcome your thoughts on the overall concepts here, knowing that I’ve tried to capture my expertise and experience for you in a transferrable way.
 
If we are headed in the right direction – I will format the “Bias Learning Journeys” attached. For now I’ve just documented the courses, trying to minimize (but not necessarily completely eliminate) redundancy with the Inclusive Leadership Journeys so that you can sell both to a given client. 
 
I’ll set up time to talk through these with some of you next week. 
 
 
Thank you 
😊
M

Hello, 
Please join me July 28
th
 , with my colleague Ada Vargas, as we prepare for Hispanic Heritage Month. 
We will provide a special preview of two LCWs educational offerings: Understanding the Latinx Experience in America and Spotlight on the Latinx Community. You can use the registration link to 
reserve up to 3 seats
 and don’t forget to schedule time with me so we can bring one of these offerings to your organization. 
See you on the 28
th
!
Tahitia Timmons
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Join us for an LCW client event: 
Preparing for Hispanic Heritage Month
 
Reserve your seat for this session now!
 
 
You've been selected by an LCW staff member for an exclusive invite to this LCW client event!
 
Throughout this one-hour event, we'll explore key experiences that tend to impact your Latinx colleagues, and share proven strategies for building cultural competence for stronger connections with the Latinx community... not only in time for Hispanic Heritage Month, but all-year-long. 
This unique event allows participants to experience LCW training activities and come together for meaningful discussion. Together we will: 
Gain insight into the depth and rich history of the Latinx community
Examine some experiences that tend to shape the identity of many who identify as members of this culture
Discuss strategies for making the Latinx community feel seen, valued, and respected all-year-long
This session is only available by invite! Use the registration link provided in this email and 
reserve up to 3 seats
 for your organization.
Make sure to reserve your seat now; seats for this session are available on a first-come basis!

subject: RE: Hispanic Heritage Month Promo and Latinx Facilitators question
body:
Hi Tahitia,
 
Two responses to the tactical question:
Did you look at Rebecca’s availability? She is able to facilitate in exceptional situations.
We have worked recently with Ricardo Nunez on Latinx content, including upskilling him on the immersion—he is familiar with our content and style
nunezenterprises@comcast.net
 
On the list of preferred vendors, we can put that on our list. LCW seems to update a list every 3 years or so, but at this point the preferred consultants are in everyone’s head.
 
Thanks,
Dan
 
 
Daniel Gough, PhD

Sarah

subject: RE: Progressive Review Links Enclosed
body:
Hi Tahitia,
 
Thanks for your patience. I was able to get into the links, and they all look good.  I think we’re ready to go with Module 2 and Module 5.  In reviewing Module 6, I found a few more things that concern me under HB& (one of my team, rather than myself did the initial review).  However, as I’m sure you know, there is a court challenge being heard today on FL’s law, so rather than put through more changes, can we hold for a day or two on that module to see if we need to make any additional adjustments (understanding there may be additional cost) depending on whether the law stays in place or not?
 
Thanks!
 
From:
 Tahitia Timmons <t.timmons@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, August 2, 2022 6:35 AM
To:
 Marisa Afzali <Marisa_Afzali@Progressive.com>
Cc:

Please find enclosed the review links for the requested changes (SOW202277).  Please let us know if these are approved (or changes needed) and we will send the upload files for your LMS.

n.barile@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Thursday, August 4, 2022 5:14 PM
To:
 Tahitia Timmons <
t.timmons@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 RE: Danaher MSA question 
 
Hey there,
 
I cannot find a more recent version, although I did find the signature page uploaded separately
https://www.dropbox.com/preview/CLIENTS/DANAHER/Background/LCW-MSA%20Signature%20Page%20I.pdf?context=standalone_preview&role=work
 
Please ask Randy if he has it saved on his computer somewhere or maybe in DocuSign.
 
Although, the date this was signed was August 26, 2020, so we will need a new MSA anyway, right, since it’s been over 1 year?
 
That said, the MSA states:
 
TERM.  This Agreement will commence on the date hereof and willexpireon the[_________][10Aug 2021]first yearanniversary thereof, unless earlier terminated in accordance with the terms of thisAgreement or 
unless the Parties agree inwriting to extend the term (the “Term”)
. The term of each SOWshall be as specified in that SOW. 
To the extent any SOWs remain in effect upon the expiration of thisAgreement pursuant to this Section 2, the Agreement shall automatically continue solely with respect tosuch SOW
(s) but no additional SOWs may be issued hereunder unless the Parties agree to renew the Termpursuant to this Section 2.
 
What we have done with other clients is to amend the MSA (not create a new one) & just extend the term.
 
So, first see if Randy has the final doc. Then share with me (if you get it), and you can loop me into the email chain so I can see if I can get them to agree to amend the term.
 
Make sense?
 
Nicole Barile
Director of Operations
, 
LCW
 
From:
 Tahitia Timmons <

Subject:

I have a request from Danaher to send a copy of our current MSA to them. I found this version, but it says draft, along with this signature page. Can you double-check if this is the newest MSA? I was told by we need an MSA agreement no older than 1 year. If we do not have one, we will need to start the MSA process with them which may take a few months. 
Also if this is it am I ok to send what I found which has track changes still on. 
Thank you

Hello, 
Please join me July 28
th
 , with my colleague Ada Vargas, as we prepare for Hispanic Heritage Month. 
We will provide a special preview of two LCWs educational offerings: Understanding the Latinx Experience in America and Spotlight on the Latinx Community. You can use the registration link to

th

Join us for an LCW client event: 
Preparing for Hispanic Heritage Month
 
Reserve your seat for this session now!
 
 
You've been selected by an LCW staff member for an exclusive invite to this LCW client event!
 
Throughout this one-hour event, we'll explore key experiences that tend to impact your Latinx colleagues, and share proven strategies for building cultural competence for stronger connections with the Latinx community... not only in time for Hispanic Heritage Month, but all-year-long. 
This unique event allows participants to experience LCW training activities and come together for meaningful discussion. Together we will: 
Gain insight into the depth and rich history of the Latinx community
Examine some experiences that tend to shape the identity of many who identify as members of this culture
Discuss strategies for making the Latinx community feel seen, valued, and respected all-year-long
This session is only available by invite! Use the registration link provided in this email and 
reserve up to 3 seats
 for your organization.
Make sure to reserve your seat now; seats for this session are available on a first-come basis!

subject: Inclusion Learning Journeys.pptx
body:
Hello folks!
Attached is an updated effort to incorporate feedback on what people liked/didn’t like in the “UTBE” Learning Journey. Of course – eventually a gorgeous formatting job from Keri/Kelly will also be needed. 
😊
 
But for now… as a first step…
 
Since each of you has expressed interest in seeing what journey maps aligned to the SCI model and Inclusive Leadership might look like–I’d love your thoughts on the attached. It is by no means PRETTY (at all) – but note I focused on:
color-coding the Inclusive Leadership Competency Framework to align with the already agreed upon graphic for the “Sustainable Culture of Inclusion Model”
creating distinct inclusive leadership learning journeys for 3 groups: 
All audiences including individual contributors 
Senior leaders
Middle managers
 
Tahitia, Andrea, Sarah, Dan and Tamara
 – I’d love you to see if you like the courses listed under each, and what you might change.
 
Chuck, Alisa, Kell, Nicole and Melissa
 – I’d welcome your thoughts on the overall concepts here, knowing that I’ve tried to capture my expertise and experience for you in a transferrable way.
 
If we are headed in the right direction – I will format the “Bias Learning Journeys” attached. For now I’ve just documented the courses, trying to minimize (but not necessarily completely eliminate) redundancy with the Inclusive Leadership Journeys so that you can sell both to a given client. 
 
I’ll set up time to talk through these with some of you next week. 
 
 
Thank you 
😊
M

subject: Accepted: Quick Catch and align on Black Exec/Latinx Sponsor Program
Follow-up items
body:
Hi Nicole, 
 Thank you for a great discussion yesterday. Please find some of the requested items. For the suggested courses and pricing, please realize that these are already existing courses and are not custom created. We can update the look and feel to reflect your branding but content changes would be considered customization. Price differences between the selections usually reflect those that are longer than 1 hour or have more than 1 facilitator. You will find off the shelf as is pricing at the end of the document. The actual SOW price may be higher or lower depending on the final configuration.
Regarding the MSA – I have a request in with that department to pull a copy of the document and will provide it once I have it. 
Also here is the free imposter syndrome training (Google sponsored)  I mentioned called #IamRemarkable  
https://iamremarkable.withgoogle.com/
Let me know if you have any questions. 
Thank you 
Tahitia

From:
