Sent:
 Thursday, August 4, 2022 5:14 PM
To:
 Tahitia Timmons <t.timmons@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Danaher MSA question 
 
Hey there,
 
I cannot find a more recent version, although I did find the signature page uploaded separately
https://www.dropbox.com/preview/CLIENTS/DANAHER/Background/LCW-MSA%20Signature%20Page%20I.pdf?context=standalone_preview&role=work
 
Please ask Randy if he has it saved on his computer somewhere or maybe in DocuSign.
 
Although, the date this was signed was August 26, 2020, so we will need a new MSA anyway, right, since it’s been over 1 year?
 
That said, the MSA states:
 
TERM.  This Agreement will commence on the date hereof and willexpireon the[_________][10Aug 2021]first yearanniversary thereof, unless earlier terminated in accordance with the terms of thisAgreement or 
unless the Parties agree inwriting to extend the term (the “Term”)
. The term of each SOWshall be as specified in that SOW. 
To the extent any SOWs remain in effect upon the expiration of thisAgreement pursuant to this Section 2, the Agreement shall automatically continue solely with respect tosuch SOW
(s) but no additional SOWs may be issued hereunder unless the Parties agree to renew the Termpursuant to this Section 2.
 
What we have done with other clients is to amend the MSA (not create a new one) & just extend the term.
 
So, first see if Randy has the final doc. Then share with me (if you get it), and you can loop me into the email chain so I can see if I can get them to agree to amend the term.
 
Make sense?
 
Nicole Barile
Director of Operations
, 
LCW

Subject:
 Please Join me July 28th - Hispanic Heritage Month Special Client Preview!
 
> 
WARNING
 - This email originated outside of Genpact.
Do 
not
 reply
, 
click on links
 or 
open attachments
 unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. If you believe the content of this email may be unsafe, please forward it as an attachment to 
thislooksphishy@genpact.com
 or use the 'This Looks Phishy' Outlook button.
Hello, 
Please join me July 28
th
 , with my colleague Ada Vargas, as we prepare for Hispanic Heritage Month. 
We will provide a special preview of two LCWs educational offerings: Understanding the Latinx Experience in America and Spotlight on the Latinx Community. You can use the registration link to 
reserve up to 3 seats
 and don’t forget to schedule time with me so we can bring one of these offerings to your organization. 
See you on the 28
th
!
Tahitia Timmons
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Join us for an LCW client event: 
Preparing for Hispanic Heritage Month
 
Reserve your seat for this session now!
 
 
You've been selected by an LCW staff member for an exclusive invite to this LCW client event!
 
Throughout this one-hour event, we'll explore key experiences that tend to impact your Latinx colleagues, and share proven strategies for building cultural competence for stronger connections with the Latinx community... not only in time for Hispanic Heritage Month, but all-year-long. 
This unique event allows participants to experience LCW training activities and come together for meaningful discussion. Together we will: 
Gain insight into the depth and rich history of the Latinx community
Examine some experiences that tend to shape the identity of many who identify as members of this culture
Discuss strategies for making the Latinx community feel seen, valued, and respected all-year-long
This session is only available by invite! Use the registration link provided in this email and 
reserve up to 3 seats
 for your organization.
Make sure to reserve your seat now; seats for this session are available on a first-come basis!

subject: RE: Our call today
body:
Hi Tamara, 
 
We’re good with holding off on the weekly meetings for a few weeks. Do you have a date in mind that you’d like to regroup? Or should we circle back on that once we have the last two stakeholder interviews scheduled? Also, Adrianne and I talked about the initial readout, and that will likely be Adrianne, Lisa, J.J. and myself. I know we still have some time, but let us know when we should start looking at dates for that. There might be one or two other groups that we want to review the findings, but we can decide on that as we get closer. 
 
One small request from me. I have a call with one of our APAC DE&I leaders and she was wondering how the APAC focus groups went. Could the team send just a few sentences that I could have on hand to send to her? My call with her is Monday evening. LMK if that works. 
 
Thanks, 
Rachel

All the best,

>
Subject:
 Our call today
 
Hi team, 
 
Adrianne is in Cannes this week, and I only have a few items on my list, so I was thinking we could share updates via email this week.  
 
LMK if that works for you, or if there was something specific you wanted to discuss today. 
 
In the meantime, below is what I have on my radar. 
Focus Groups
EMEA
: Confirmed and on the calendar for 7/6.
APAC:
 Waiting to hear back from the facilitator about additional times for July. 
US API:
 Waiting to hear back from the facilitator. At this point Thursday, 7/7: 11am-12pm CT is probably the best option so let me know if I should look at the second/third weeks of July too. 
1:1 Stakeholder Interviews
Scheduling
: LCW working on time blocks. I also have a meeting with Lisa Moehlenkamp tomorrow to give her a heads up that we’re starting to schedule. 
Questions:
 FH/LCW to finalize questions. 
I know your team is working on those based on our conversation last week. 
To Adrianne’s point on the call, we think there are three “themes” to these conversations: Personal commitment, accountability (for themselves and others) and I also think hearing their perspective on existing barriers or challenges that make it harder for them or their teams to make inclusion a priority, such as business demands from the firm. 
Also, if there are any other themes that have emerged from the focus groups that we want to ask about, such as the point that Dan brought up about utilization, that is great too. 
I also gave this some thought so sharing some ideas below. 
What personal goals/commitments have you made as it relates to DE&I? Can you share an example of actions that have supported those commitments?
As a leader, how are you holding yourself accountable? How do you hold other leaders and managers on your team accountable?
Where does DE&I fit in with your other business priorities?
Would love thoughts on this one. I think it’s easy to say that DE&I is a priority but actually practicing that is more difficult. I think our focus on utilization is a great example. So I want to ask a question that digs into what DE&I being a priority looks like 
in action
 for these leaders beyond just  “voicing support.” 
From the GM deck: Which processes or policies limit or enhance a culture of inclusion and sense of belonging at FleishmanHillard? What is working or not working?
DE&I Certification Exploratory Conversation: Confirmed for 6/30
 
LMK if there is anything I missed. 
 
Thanks!
Rachel

LMK if there is anything I missed. 
 
Thanks!

I believe you are referencing Chris’s comments to us in the email (not on the doc), right? If so, I would not pass those questions along at this point.
Genpact will respond to his redlines. They shouldn’t need any other info.
Usually I just tell the client “Please see the redlines from our legal team for your review.” (something like that) 
😊

And if you want me to respond to Genpact with the info & redlines I can. Just lmk!

ccramer@epclawyers.com
> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, August 3, 2022 6:20 PM
To:
 Nicole Barile <
n.barile@lcwmail.com
>
Cc:
 Tahitia Timmons <
t.timmons@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 RE: Genpact SOW
 
Nicole –
 
My comments/questions are in the attached redline.  It appears the Protected Data is limited to the email addresses of Genpact’s Diversity and Inclusion Team, at least that is what I gathered from Schedule 1.  I have modified part of the DPA accordingly based on that understanding.  Assuming that is correct, the concerns relating to the Personal Data obligations and restrictions is not as concerning as the protected class and data set is severely limited.  This could a larger concern, though, if there is a future amendment or SOW that expands the class or data set to a broader group.
 
Please review, and let me know if you have any questions.
 
 
 
 
Christopher W. Cramer

 Genpact SOW
 
Hi Chris,
 
Our client, Genpact, has requested to add a lot of legal language to the SOW. I reviewed myself & was OK with most things.
I thought you should review as well in case I’m missing something.
The only things that caught my eye were 8.2 & 8.3 regarding subcontractors. There is a possibility we may use external consultants, and we would not know that at this time, nor would we want the client to approve the subcontractors or think it’s reasonable to share the subcontractors’ contact information. 
Kindly review & let us know what you find.
 
I’m also attaching the MSA that was signed pre me – back in 2020.
 
I’ll be OOO this Fri-next Tues, so I’m copying Tahitia who can assist if needed. This is her client.
 
Thanks so much!
Nicole

My comments/questions are in the attached redline.  It appears the Protected Data is limited to the email addresses of Genpact’s Diversity and Inclusion Team, at least that is what I gathered from Schedule 1.  I have modified part of the DPA accordingly based on that understanding.  Assuming that is correct, the concerns relating to the Personal Data obligations and restrictions is not as concerning as the protected class and data set is severely limited.  This could a larger concern, though, if there is a future amendment or SOW that expands the class or data set to a broader group.
 
Please review, and let me know if you have any questions.
 
 
 
 
Christopher W. Cramer

subject: RE: Process/SOP template
body:
Hi Tahitia,
Thanks for working on this. I’m slammed this week catching up, but I did take a look. I like how it looks a lot; however, I’m wondering how long it will make the processes. It does look more like an SOP, as you mention, not a process doc. Ideally, I was looking for something short – like 1 or 2 pages. But I’m open to other things – I just want to make this as simple as possible. Maybe this will work just fine, as long as we can keep some sections rather short.
 
I will take more of a look next week and will try to make that call with you & Grace.
Perhaps you try taking one of the existing process docs from the Processes Library to see how it fits this & how long it will be??
 
Thanks again!
 
Nicole Barile
Director of Operations
, 
LCW

subject: Accepted: Quick Catch and align on Black Exec/Latinx Sponsor Program
FW: Learning Session 3 for Sponsors and Managers (D+I Executive Sponsorship Program)
body:
Here you go!
 
 
Confidential - Company Proprietary
From:
 Roane, Arlene <arlene.roane@danaher.com> 
Sent:
 Thursday, June 23, 2022 10:32 AM
To:
 Ellis, Brian W <brian.ellis@danaher.com>
Cc:
 Wormley, Nicole A <nicole.wormley@danaher.com>; Butler, Jason <jason.butler@danaher.com>
Subject:
 Re: Learning Session 3 for Sponsors and Managers (D+I Executive Sponsorship Program)
 
 
Greetings,
 
Circling back with everyone with an update on the proposed content for session 3 of the Black Executive Sponsorship Program.
Speakers/Panelists
Jason and I discussed and agreed to invite Shane Sanders, Danaher Board of Directors & Audit Committee, as one of the speakers.   We need to balance the program with the voice and experience of a Black female senior executive.  Possible speakers include:
 
Shellye Archambeau 
former CEO MetricStream, Board member for Verizon, Nordstrom, Roper Technologies, and Okta Inc. 
 
Linda Clement-Holmes 
Retired CIO The Procter & Gamble Company 
 
Carla Harris 
Vice Chairman and Managing Director, Morgan Stanley 
 
Beverly Anderson 
Former President Global Consumer Solutions Equifax, Board Director Equifax 
 
Sylvia Russel 
Past President ATT Southern Region 
 
 
 
Moderator/Presenter
Recommend hiring an experienced moderator, with current/former experience as a Black senior corporate executive.  Recommendations:
Charles Adams
Managing Principle at LCW, former senior executive at AON
 
Gail Johnson
CHRO at the Executive Leadership Council, former senior executive at ATT
 
 
Program Format
Recommend a hybrid format combining live participation and previously recorded video.  The moderator/presenter will be live.  One or both panelists could be captured via video if not available for a live session.  A hybrid format will facilitate delivery by minimizing scheduling challenges.
 
Please share your agreement/disagreement, thoughts, and recommendations as soon as possible.   I would like to secure commitments from the panelists and moderator within the next 2-3 weeks.   The target delivery for the program is September/October.
 
 
Regards,
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
From:
 Roane, Arlene <
arlene.roane@danaher.com
>
Sent:
 Monday, May 23, 2022 8:40 AM
To:
 Ellis, Brian W <
brian.ellis@danaher.com
>
Subject:
 Fw: Learning Session 3 for Sponsors and Managers (D+I Executive Sponsorship Program)
 
 
Brian,
 
In addition to my note below,  I spoke with Gail Coles Johnson, ELC CHRO.   She's a former HRVP from ATT, where she led executive development.    I asked her if she would consider being the moderator.    We also talked about other options for Danaher involvement in the ELC in addition to sponsoring members.   
 
Looking forward to connecting.
 
Arlene
 
  
From:
 Roane, Arlene <
arlene.roane@danaher.com
>
Sent:
 Friday, May 20, 2022 6:13 AM
To:
 Butler, Jason <
jason.butler@danaher.com
>; Wormley, Nicole A <
nicole.wormley@danaher.com
>
Cc:
 Quattlebaum, Michelle <
michelle.quattlebaum@danaher.com
>
Subject:
 Re: Learning Session 3 for Sponsors and Managers (D+I Executive Sponsorship Program)
 
 
Nicole --
 
I agree.  Per our conversation last week, our goal is to feature at least a Black male and a Black female in current or former C-level roles.  Finding the right individuals with the backgrounds and career paths that are comparable to Danaher senior leaders has been challenging.    I have enlisted the assistance of members of the Executive Leadership Council (ELC) and have asked a senior ELC staff member for assistance.    Additionally,  Brian Ellis, a former active member of the ELC, is also providing guidance, support, as well as access to his network.
 
Here is a short list of potential speakers/panelists known to be excellent speakers on the topic of navigating challenges as a Black executive.   
 
Carla Harris 
Vice Chairman and Managing Director, Morgan Stanley 
 
Beverly Anderson 
Former President Global Consumer Solutions Equifax, Board Director Equifax 
 
Sylvia Russel 
Past President ATT Southern Region 
 
Reggie Van Lee 
Chief Transformation Officer The Carlyle Group, former Executive Vice President Booz Allen & Hamilton  
 
Shellye Archambeau 
former CEO MetricStream, Board member for Verizon, Nordstrom, Roper Technologies and Okta Inc. 
 
Ben-Saba Hassan 
SVP Chief Culture Diversity Equity & Inclusion Officer, Walmart Inc., Former SVP Info Division Services Walmart, Inc. 
 
Linda Clement-Holmes 
Retired CIO The Procter & Gamble Company 
 
Oris Stuart 
EVP National Basketball Association, Board Director Ameritas, Former Senior Partner Korn Ferry 
 
Each person on the list is accessible via a direct or indirect relationship.  I will continue to search for Black executives with experience leading global operations or manufacturing in the health tech or pharma industries.
 
 
Best, 
Arlene
 
 
 
From:
 Butler, Jason <
jason.butler@danaher.com
>
Sent:
 Thursday, May 19, 2022 10:09 AM
To:
 Wormley, Nicole A <
nicole.wormley@danaher.com
>; Roane, Arlene <
arlene.roane@danaher.com
>
Cc:
 Quattlebaum, Michelle <
michelle.quattlebaum@danaher.com
>
Subject:
 RE: Learning Session 3 for Sponsors and Managers (D+I Executive Sponsorship Program)
 
 
Hey Nicole – Yes we should postpone Learning Session #3 and the note is good.  We will continue to work to identify a speaker. 
 
Jason Butler | Senior Director of Diversity & Inclusion, Human Resources 
Cell: +1.708.218.0068

>

Arlene/Jason,
 
Unless I don’t hear back from you both tomorrow, I am going to cancel the Lesson 3 sessions with the following note tomorrow late afternoon:
 
>>>>>>>>> 
 
Sponsors and Managers, I regret to inform you that we will be cancelling/postponing our Learning Session 3. We had an issue with a speaker that we were hoping to rectify but was unable to do so. 
 
The remaining sessions will be scheduled as planned.
 
Thanks in advance for your understanding.
Nicole
 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>

Arlene,
 
Are we good to go to cancel this with the “postponed” messaging we discussed?
 
Nicole

Hello Nicole,
 
Please accept this request to postpone this program as more time to secure panelists/speakers.  Here is the program overview for session 3.  
 
 
Recently, I have enlisted assistance from Brian Ellis, as former ELC member.  Both he and I are mobilizing our networks to locate Black senior executives who will effectively deliver a message that resonates with the Black associates AND who have the industry and senior operational experience that will resonate with the sponsors.
 
Please let me know how I can help deliver the appropriate message to the Sponsorship Program participants.
 
Best,
Arlene

body:

I really like this! I’ve put some thoughts and notes in the attached, in case helpful, but I love how you’ve set it up. Agree with keeping 5, this is for me the most important part of these documents (clearly I’m a visual learner 
😊
) but also I find the process view to be so useful for accountability. I think 6 is important because it has space for us to indicate related documents and materials that support that process. But we could also find another way to include that.
 
Happy to help however I can.
 
Thanks!
Grace

 Tahitia Timmons <t.timmons@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Genpact SOW
 
Hi Chris,
 
Our client, Genpact, has requested to add a lot of legal language to the SOW. I reviewed myself & was OK with most things.
I thought you should review as well in case I’m missing something.
The only things that caught my eye were 8.2 & 8.3 regarding subcontractors. There is a possibility we may use external consultants, and we would not know that at this time, nor would we want the client to approve the subcontractors or think it’s reasonable to share the subcontractors’ contact information. 
Kindly review & let us know what you find.
 
I’m also attaching the MSA that was signed pre me – back in 2020.
 
I’ll be OOO this Fri-next Tues, so I’m copying Tahitia who can assist if needed. This is her client.
 
Thanks so much!
Nicole
 
Nicole Barile
Director of Operations

subject: Open collective conference Aug 18th 11am -5pm
body:
Hi, 
This is an open collective conference. No prep really needed but I think you would be awesome as this is usually the type of space where you lead a guided discussion around a topic you choose. I cc’d you on an email I sent to one of the organizers about you. I even think the podcast topic you did would be great for this. I am not sure how many attendees this will have but it is another way to get your name and brand out there. (the honorarium is very small fyi – but the concept and people are great because they are justice-oriented)
https://www.reimaginingunconference.com/
 
Thanks

Hi Edward, 
Great discussion today!
Attached is a proposed quote which can always be modified. I included the facilitated learnings we discussed and three micro learnings with pricing. I have these at 25 users and 6 months (they are not doing 12 months).  There were also price increases since the list you shared and I cannot override them BUT I was able to still have the 25% show up, however that is contingent on the prepay and 4+ and will no longer be available moving forward

subject: Calendly Product Update - July 2022
body:
Do more than share your scheduling link... 
Hi Tahitia,
This is Jeff, head of product marketing for Calendly. I’d love to share a few tips and product updates with you.
 
Tip of the Day: Scheduling with a teammate
This shouldn’t surprise you, but I spend a lot of time reading customers’ tweets and other social media posts about Calendly. Know what one of the most surprising requests is?
“I wish I could use Calendly to bring my coworker into a meeting.”"
We have the feature! It’s 
Collective Scheduling
, one of our 
multi-person scheduling options
.
 
Imagine using Collective event types to:
Team up with a subject-matter expert to close a sales deal with a prospect
Join your colleague for a meeting with a freelancer or agency
Convince a new recruit to join your company — together with a hiring manager
Collective-scheduling proponent and Square’s partnership manager Winta Habteslassie
 puts the pain best: “It was so difficult to manage three or four different calendars across the board. And by the time I would find an open slot and a partner would get back to me, I’d have to go back and forth, telling them ‘hey I'm sorry, actually those days and times that I provided to you are no longer available.’” 
Read Winta’s experience with Collective event types in this blog post
.
Try Collective Scheduling
Routing Forms Update: Tool for Developers
Entrepreneur Yaron Hadad
 says, “I love Calendly Routing Forms.”
If you’re unfamiliar, our Routing Forms feature lets you “qualify,” or request information from potential meeting attendees, and then automatically direct them to a specific scheduling page or website based on their responses.   
Now, 
software developers can build third-party workflow applications that programmatically pull Routing Form responses out of Calendly via our API
. This enables teams to trigger automated workflows the moment an individual submits a form.
Learn More
Mobile Apps: Get more scheduling flexibility
We are constantly improving Calendly’s mobile apps for 
iOS
 and 
Android
. Our 
latest improvements
 add more of the functionality you’re accustomed to, as well as a few that make so much more sense when you’re on the go:
Expanded options for sharing your availability:
 Create and share a QR code for an Event Type, customize the message that accompanies your shared links, and more.
Easier rescheduling for invitees:
 Send a rescheduling-specific link that lets invitees choose a new date/time on your calendar, or reschedule the meeting on behalf of the invitee.
Manage your availability from anywhere:
 It’s now easier than ever to quickly adjust your time zone because you’re traveling, or block out specific days because of prior engagement, or adjust your availability for personal time off.
Learn More
Featured Integrations: Google Analytics & Facebook Pixel
Understanding customer traffic and conversion rates is a critical aspect of marketing your business. 
Our 
Google Analytics
 and 
Facebook (Meta) Pixel
 integrations enable Calendly users to track the effectiveness of scheduling and Facebook campaigns where users are directed to a Calendly booking call-to-action (CTA). With this information, marketers can gain insights into their campaigns and create more specific targeting and ads. 
Now, both of these integrations can track events related to Calendly’s 
Routing Forms
 feature. With these updates, teams can use Facebook Pixels or Google Analytics to understand how their routing forms are performing and converting. For example, imagine analyzing when a prospect lands on and submits a routing form.   
 
Learn More
Additional Resources
Assign high-volume meetings more efficiently with Round Robin
The Time Economy customer survey results
Team scheduling options overview
Thanks for reading, 
Jeff Hardison
Head of Product Marketing 
Calendly
 
 
 
 
Sent from Calendly
88 N Avondale Rd #603
Avondale Estates, GA 30002

subject: Thank you for attending "Preparing for Hispanic Heritage Month"
body:
Please take our survey and reach out with any questions!
 
View this email in your browser
 
 
Hi Tahitia,
Thank you for attending yesterday's session, 
Preparing for Hispanic Heritage Month
.
 We appreciated your time, chat messages, and poll participation – your contributions to this discussion are what make these sessions impactful and unique!
If you have not done so already, please take a moment to complete the survey below on your experience so we can continue to improve our client sessions.
Take the survey
 
Yesterday's event featured activities from two of LCW's course offerings:
Cultural Immersion: Understanding the Latinx 
Experience in the U.S. Today
 
This 4-hour session allows participants to take a deep look at the complexities of being Latinx (Hispanic / Latino/a) in the United States and at the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of America’s Latinx community. The session explores key concepts such as the rich diversity within the Latinx community, current key issues and events impacting Latinx experience and perspectives, understanding and responding to stereotypes, and analyzing the intent versus impact of common messaging and missed opportunities for connection with the Latinx community today.
Spotlight on the Latinx Community
 
Spotlight on the Latinx Community is an interactive one-hour session that explores the Latinx experience. This session debunks myths, unpacks stereotypes, and builds actionable insight around the Hispanic and Latinx experience both inside and outside the office.
Please reply to this email if you'd like to learn more about any of LCW's course offerings or schedule time to speak with me 
here
.
I hope to hear from you soon!
Best,
Melissa Neu
Business Development Consultant
Want to talk? Schedule time with me 
here
!

From:
 Rubano, Karen <Karen.Rubano@sbdinc.com> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, July 27, 2022 1:37 PM
To:
 Daniel Gough <d.gough@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Tahitia Timmons <t.timmons@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Hello from Stanley Black & Decker
 
Hello Daniel! 
 
I am a member of the Stanley Black & Decker DEI team and have enjoyed a relationship with LCW since my start date, 12/2020.  Our team has enjoyed a relationship with LCW since 2018.  Two LCW products have reached an extensive SBD audience:  (1) Managing Unconscious Bias 30 minute e-learning for all new hires, and (2) Managing Unconscious Bias in the Workplace 3 hour workshop for all people managers.
 
This past week our Legal team asked for a transcription and associated slides for the Managing Unconscious Bias 30 minute e-learning for all new hires.  I believe due diligence on eLearning content is under review.  It was an urgent request, and we didn’t have anything to share minus the eLearning itself.  I reached out to Tahitia who took the ball with urgency and within 24 hours, delivered on the transcript, and within another business day, a visual document mirroring the eLearning content/graphics.  I know Tahitia had to figure out what teams to go to and had the sense of urgency on her mind – and she delivered.  She asked the right questions, and provided SBD what we needed in a professional and timely manner.  It was an unexpected ask which I am sure put a hiccup in her time.  
 
Tahitia is also doing a lot of thinking regarding the content currency and Train the Trainer design of our 3 hours workshop, which is no longer sustainable for us.  She has great ideas and much depth.  I am impressed!  
 
Too often in a vendor relationship, good work goes unnoticed.  I did not want that to happen.  Tahitia is an asset to LCW!  We are so happy to partner with her.  I hope this makes your day to know it.  
😊
 
Karen
 
Karen Rubano

Hello, 
Do either of you care if for the quiz the bulk of the information for the questions goes in the chat? I was slightly concerned around timing and not feeling like I was speed talking through it.  I am highlighting what I will say out loud the rest would go in the chat.
Would love feedback. 
Thanks
 
0:19 to 0:23 (4 minutes = 3 minutes for quiz + 1 minute for debrief of Q1; note rest of questions debriefed on next slide)
FAC B
OPEN POLL 1: Let’s do a quiz… (FACILITATOR: Quiz/Poll questions are in separate Word document in UTLE folder.)
Debrief q#1 = 1 min
Say: Here’s a pop quiz about facts and history about the Latinx community in the U.S. No googling allowed.
 [Give people 3 minutes to complete quiz.]. 
After everyone is done with quiz, go through and debrief answers 1 by 1.  
Quiz question #1: People whose cultural background or heritage is Latin American prefer to identify as:
The answer is ‘any of the above.’ Different people prefer to identify differently.  
Inoculate the question “Just tell me what to call them” by proactively bringing it up – 
 When in doubt, just ask the person, how do you identify?
Hispanic
 refers to 
language 
– someone with origins in a Spanish speaking country. This includes Spain but not countries like Brazil (Portuguese) or Haiti (Haitian Creole- based largely on French).
 [If anyone asks: Belize (ENG), Guyana (ENG), Suriname (Dutch), and French Guiana (French)]. 
Latino/a
 relates to 
geographic location
 – meaning a person whose country of origin is within Latin America (Central and South America and the Caribbean). This includes people with cultural background in the non-Spanish speaking countries like Brazil.
Latinx
 is being used more and more, especially by younger people, as a gender-neutral word for Latino/a identity. It includes people of any gender or gender identity. 
Chicano
 refers to Mexican-American heritage. It’s also associated with the Mexican-American labor and civil rights movement of the 1960’s and 70’s. For many Mexican Americans, it connotes pride in a shared cultural, ethnic and community identity.
Country of origin:
 Many people prefer to identify not only as Latino or Hispanic, but also or primarily with their country of origin, e.g., as Guatemalan-American, Mexican-American, Venezuelan, or Cuban-American. 
Other: Boricua
 means Puerto Rican – it comes from the indigenous Puerto Ricans’ name for the island: Borikén or Borinquen. 
Spanish
 - Some people call Latinos “Spanish” – but what does Spanish mean? Right, that you’re from Spain.
I will be referring to American residents of Latin American origin interchangeably as Latinx, Latino, and Hispanic.
 
Transition
: 
Okay, let’s move on to q#2, what percent of the population identifies as Latinx? 
MOVE TO NEXT SLIDE TO DEBRIEF Q #2
                LATINX image adapted from: 
https://www.elle.com/culture/career-politics/a38249/latinx-activists-roundtable/
 
 
Debrief remaining questions – provide answer key in a handout to save time
2. Q2: The answer is (e). 
Latinos represent 18.7% of the U.S. population 
or about 62.1 million people (2020 census).
 
Other answers
: 12.4% Black non-Latino, 10.2% two or more races, 6% Asian, 1.1% Am Indian & Alaska Native (
If asked:
 .2% Hawaiian and Pacific Islander and 61.6% white)
.
Source: 
https://www.census.gov/library/visualizations/interactive/race-and-ethnicity-in-the-united-state-2010-and-2020-census.html
Latinos are the largest U.S. minority and the 2nd fastest growing ethnic group (after Asians) in the US. The US Census predicts the Latino pop will reach almost 30% of the population by 2060.
This 
table shows the countries of origin for different Latino groups in the US. 
From the most recent 2020 US Census.
As you can see people of Mexican origin represent the biggest group – 
61.5%
 / 
9.7% 
are Puerto Rican / Salvadoran and Cuban Latinos make up almost 
4% each
 / 
3.4%
 Dominican / 
2.7%
 Guatemalan/ Colombia 2%, Honduras 1.8%
3. [Q5 in UTLE Quiz]. The first European language spoken in what is now the United States was: (a) English, (b) Dutch, (c) Portuguese, 
(d) Spanish,
 (e) French
.
 In 1565 - 
The first permanent European settlement, Saint Augustine, Florida, is established in what is now the U.S. by Spanish admiral Pedro Menéndez de Avilés, 
introducing Catholicism and the Spanish language to the nation
. 
Note that this was 42 years 
before
 the first permanent English settlement, Jamestown, VA, was established 1607.
 
4. [Q7 in UTLE Quiz]. True or 
False:
 About 25% of the 500k-2 million Mexicans deported by the U.S. in the 1930’s were American citizens. 
EXPLAIN: 
In the prework that we have to prepare people for the full 4-hour Cultural Immersion, they have a chance to watch a short video and read some articles that include important history—like this about the mass deportations of Mexicans and Mexican Americans from the U.S., that took place called the 
“Mexican Repatriation” which took place during the Great Depression
 
(1929-36).
The answer is False – the answer is 60%
. (If anyone asks, the vast majority were birthright citizens). Latinos were widely 
blamed for exacerbating the overall economic consequences of the Great Depression.
While supported by the federal government, 
many of the deportations were largely organized and carried out by city and state governments, with support from private companies. For this reason it’s nearly impossible to quantify the exact number of people who were deported.
Transition
: Let’s watch a video to kick off some key historical events for Latinx in the U.S. 
============================================================================
Sources:
https://www.nationalgeographic.com/magazine/2020/07/latinos-hispanic-power-america-immigration-future/
2016 American Community Survey (HISPANIC OR LATINO BY SPECIFIC ORIGIN) - 
https://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/ACS/16_1YR/B03001
)

Hello, 
Do either of you care if for the quiz the bulk of the information for the questions goes in the chat? I was slightly concerned around timing and not feeling like I was speed talking through it.  I am highlighting what I will say out loud the rest would go in the chat.
Would love feedback. 
Thanks
 
0:19 to 0:23 (4 minutes = 3 minutes for quiz + 1 minute for debrief of Q1; note rest of questions debriefed on next slide)
FAC B
OPEN POLL 1: Let’s do a quiz… (FACILITATOR: Quiz/Poll questions are in separate Word document in UTLE folder.)
Debrief q#1 = 1 min
Say: Here’s a pop quiz about facts and history about the Latinx community in the U.S. No googling allowed.
 [Give people 3 minutes to complete quiz.]. 
After everyone is done with quiz, go through and debrief answers 1 by 1.  
Quiz question #1: People whose cultural background or heritage is Latin American prefer to identify as:
The answer is ‘any of the above.’ Different people prefer to identify differently.  
Inoculate the question “Just tell me what to call them” by proactively bringing it up – 
 When in doubt, just ask the person, how do you identify?
Hispanic
 refers to 
language 
– someone with origins in a Spanish speaking country. This includes Spain but not countries like Brazil (Portuguese) or Haiti (Haitian Creole- based largely on French).
 [If anyone asks: Belize (ENG), Guyana (ENG), Suriname (Dutch), and French Guiana (French)]. 
Latino/a
 relates to 
geographic location
 – meaning a person whose country of origin is within Latin America (Central and South America and the Caribbean). This includes people with cultural background in the non-Spanish speaking countries like Brazil.
Latinx
 is being used more and more, especially by younger people, as a gender-neutral word for Latino/a identity. It includes people of any gender or gender identity. 
Chicano
 refers to Mexican-American heritage. It’s also associated with the Mexican-American labor and civil rights movement of the 1960’s and 70’s. For many Mexican Americans, it connotes pride in a shared cultural, ethnic and community identity.
Country of origin:
 Many people prefer to identify not only as Latino or Hispanic, but also or primarily with their country of origin, e.g., as Guatemalan-American, Mexican-American, Venezuelan, or Cuban-American. 
Other: Boricua
 means Puerto Rican – it comes from the indigenous Puerto Ricans’ name for the island: Borikén or Borinquen. 
Spanish
 - Some people call Latinos “Spanish” – but what does Spanish mean? Right, that you’re from Spain.
I will be referring to American residents of Latin American origin interchangeably as Latinx, Latino, and Hispanic.
 
Transition
: 
Okay, let’s move on to q#2, what percent of the population identifies as Latinx? 
MOVE TO NEXT SLIDE TO DEBRIEF Q #2
                LATINX image adapted from: 
https://www.elle.com/culture/career-politics/a38249/latinx-activists-roundtable/
 
 
Debrief remaining questions – provide answer key in a handout to save time
2. Q2: The answer is (e). 
Latinos represent 18.7% of the U.S. population 
or about 62.1 million people (2020 census).
 
Other answers
: 12.4% Black non-Latino, 10.2% two or more races, 6% Asian, 1.1% Am Indian & Alaska Native (
If asked:
 .2% Hawaiian and Pacific Islander and 61.6% white)
.
Source: 
https://www.census.gov/library/visualizations/interactive/race-and-ethnicity-in-the-united-state-2010-and-2020-census.html
Latinos are the largest U.S. minority and the 2nd fastest growing ethnic group (after Asians) in the US. The US Census predicts the Latino pop will reach almost 30% of the population by 2060.
This 
table shows the countries of origin for different Latino groups in the US. 
From the most recent 2020 US Census.
As you can see people of Mexican origin represent the biggest group – 
61.5%
 / 
9.7% 
are Puerto Rican / Salvadoran and Cuban Latinos make up almost 
4% each
 / 
3.4%
 Dominican / 
2.7%
 Guatemalan/ Colombia 2%, Honduras 1.8%
3. [Q5 in UTLE Quiz]. The first European language spoken in what is now the United States was: (a) English, (b) Dutch, (c) Portuguese, 
(d) Spanish,
 (e) French
.
 In 1565 - 
The first permanent European settlement, Saint Augustine, Florida, is established in what is now the U.S. by Spanish admiral Pedro Menéndez de Avilés, 
introducing Catholicism and the Spanish language to the nation
. 
Note that this was 42 years 
before
 the first permanent English settlement, Jamestown, VA, was established 1607.
 
4. [Q7 in UTLE Quiz]. True or 
False:
 About 25% of the 500k-2 million Mexicans deported by the U.S. in the 1930’s were American citizens. 
EXPLAIN: 
In the prework that we have to prepare people for the full 4-hour Cultural Immersion, they have a chance to watch a short video and read some articles that include important history—like this about the mass deportations of Mexicans and Mexican Americans from the U.S., that took place called the 
“Mexican Repatriation” which took place during the Great Depression
 
(1929-36).
The answer is False – the answer is 60%
. (If anyone asks, the vast majority were birthright citizens). Latinos were widely 
blamed for exacerbating the overall economic consequences of the Great Depression.
While supported by the federal government, 
many of the deportations were largely organized and carried out by city and state governments, with support from private companies. For this reason it’s nearly impossible to quantify the exact number of people who were deported.
Transition
: Let’s watch a video to kick off some key historical events for Latinx in the U.S. 
============================================================================
Sources:
https://www.nationalgeographic.com/magazine/2020/07/latinos-hispanic-power-america-immigration-future/
2016 American Community Survey (HISPANIC OR LATINO BY SPECIFIC ORIGIN) - 
https://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/ACS/16_1YR/B03001
)

Quiz question #1: People whose cultural background or heritage is Latin American prefer to identify as:
The answer is ‘any of the above.’ Different people prefer to identify differently.  
Inoculate the question “Just tell me what to call them” by proactively bringing it up – 
 When in doubt, just ask the person, how do you identify?
Hispanic
 refers to 
language 
– someone with origins in a Spanish speaking country. This includes Spain but not countries like Brazil (Portuguese) or Haiti (Haitian Creole- based largely on French).
 [If anyone asks: Belize (ENG), Guyana (ENG), Suriname (Dutch), and French Guiana (French)]. 
Latino/a
 relates to 
geographic location
 – meaning a person whose country of origin is within Latin America (Central and South America and the Caribbean). This includes people with cultural background in the non-Spanish speaking countries like Brazil.
Latinx
 is being used more and more, especially by younger people, as a gender-neutral word for Latino/a identity. It includes people of any gender or gender identity. 
Chicano
 refers to Mexican-American heritage. It’s also associated with the Mexican-American labor and civil rights movement of the 1960’s and 70’s. For many Mexican Americans, it connotes pride in a shared cultural, ethnic and community identity.
Country of origin:
 Many people prefer to identify not only as Latino or Hispanic, but also or primarily with their country of origin, e.g., as Guatemalan-American, Mexican-American, Venezuelan, or Cuban-American. 
Other: Boricua
 means Puerto Rican – it comes from the indigenous Puerto Ricans’ name for the island: Borikén or Borinquen. 
Spanish
 - Some people call Latinos “Spanish” – but what does Spanish mean? Right, that you’re from Spain.
I will be referring to American residents of Latin American origin interchangeably as Latinx, Latino, and Hispanic.
 
Transition
: 
Okay, let’s move on to q#2, what percent of the population identifies as Latinx? 
MOVE TO NEXT SLIDE TO DEBRIEF Q #2
                LATINX image adapted from: 
https://www.elle.com/culture/career-politics/a38249/latinx-activists-roundtable/
 
 
Debrief remaining questions – provide answer key in a handout to save time
2. Q2: The answer is (e). 
Latinos represent 18.7% of the U.S. population 
or about 62.1 million people (2020 census).
 
Other answers
: 12.4% Black non-Latino, 10.2% two or more races, 6% Asian, 1.1% Am Indian & Alaska Native (
If asked:
 .2% Hawaiian and Pacific Islander and 61.6% white)
.
Source: 
https://www.census.gov/library/visualizations/interactive/race-and-ethnicity-in-the-united-state-2010-and-2020-census.html
Latinos are the largest U.S. minority and the 2nd fastest growing ethnic group (after Asians) in the US. The US Census predicts the Latino pop will reach almost 30% of the population by 2060.
This 
table shows the countries of origin for different Latino groups in the US. 
From the most recent 2020 US Census.
As you can see people of Mexican origin represent the biggest group – 
61.5%
 / 
9.7% 
are Puerto Rican / Salvadoran and Cuban Latinos make up almost 
4% each
 / 
3.4%
 Dominican / 
2.7%
 Guatemalan/ Colombia 2%, Honduras 1.8%
3. [Q5 in UTLE Quiz]. The first European language spoken in what is now the United States was: (a) English, (b) Dutch, (c) Portuguese, 
(d) Spanish,
 (e) French
.
 In 1565 - 
The first permanent European settlement, Saint Augustine, Florida, is established in what is now the U.S. by Spanish admiral Pedro Menéndez de Avilés, 
introducing Catholicism and the Spanish language to the nation
. 
Note that this was 42 years 
before
 the first permanent English settlement, Jamestown, VA, was established 1607.
 
4. [Q7 in UTLE Quiz]. True or 
False:
 About 25% of the 500k-2 million Mexicans deported by the U.S. in the 1930’s were American citizens. 
EXPLAIN: 
In the prework that we have to prepare people for the full 4-hour Cultural Immersion, they have a chance to watch a short video and read some articles that include important history—like this about the mass deportations of Mexicans and Mexican Americans from the U.S., that took place called the 
“Mexican Repatriation” which took place during the Great Depression
 
(1929-36).
The answer is False – the answer is 60%
. (If anyone asks, the vast majority were birthright citizens). Latinos were widely 
blamed for exacerbating the overall economic consequences of the Great Depression.
While supported by the federal government, 
many of the deportations were largely organized and carried out by city and state governments, with support from private companies. For this reason it’s nearly impossible to quantify the exact number of people who were deported.
Transition
: Let’s watch a video to kick off some key historical events for Latinx in the U.S. 
============================================================================
Sources:
https://www.nationalgeographic.com/magazine/2020/07/latinos-hispanic-power-america-immigration-future/
2016 American Community Survey (HISPANIC OR LATINO BY SPECIFIC ORIGIN) - 
https://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/ACS/16_1YR/B03001
)

nd

rd

Nicole

Hello, Happy “Touchbase Tuesday”! I have Arlene’s documents and would like to begin to finalize the Panel discussion for the Black Executive Sponsor Program. I wanted to follow up on a few items: ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍ ‍

Hello, 
Happy “Touchbase Tuesday”!  I have Arlene’s documents and would like to begin to finalize the Panel discussion for the Black Executive Sponsor Program. 
I wanted to follow up on a few items: 
Would you be able to introduce my group here to Jason who I have listed as my main contact for both the Black Executive and Latinx Executive programs, so we can create a meeting cadence 
The names of the two IDIs that need to be completed (I will send a separate SOW so we can get those done)
How many participants will be in the Latinx program – Is there crossover between the two groups? I am attempting to get a total number of IDIs that group may need. 
 
I can also work with Jason to get this information – I just would need an introduction. 
 
Thank you 
Tahitia

subject: RE: Our call today
body:
Hi Tamara and team, 
 
Thanks for the update! Glad to hear the two meetings have gone well! I know Adrianne is looking forward to hers later today. The revised questions also look good. 
 
We’re aligned with cancelling today’s call. The only thing on my list is we’re waiting on some updated availability for the last two stakeholder meetings. They’ve all been given a heads up by Adrianne that these are coming and are looking forward to them, so once we have those new dates, we can start working with their admins to get them on the books. 
 
Thanks!
Rachel

Tamara

Cc:
 Adrianne Smith (FleishmanHillard) <
adrianne.smith@fleishman.com
>
Subject:
 Our call today
 
Hi team, 
 
Adrianne is in Cannes this week, and I only have a few items on my list, so I was thinking we could share updates via email this week.  
 
LMK if that works for you, or if there was something specific you wanted to discuss today. 
 
In the meantime, below is what I have on my radar. 
Focus Groups
EMEA
: Confirmed and on the calendar for 7/6.
APAC:
 Waiting to hear back from the facilitator about additional times for July. 
US API:
 Waiting to hear back from the facilitator. At this point Thursday, 7/7: 11am-12pm CT is probably the best option so let me know if I should look at the second/third weeks of July too. 
1:1 Stakeholder Interviews
Scheduling
: LCW working on time blocks. I also have a meeting with Lisa Moehlenkamp tomorrow to give her a heads up that we’re starting to schedule. 
Questions:
 FH/LCW to finalize questions. 
I know your team is working on those based on our conversation last week. 
To Adrianne’s point on the call, we think there are three “themes” to these conversations: Personal commitment, accountability (for themselves and others) and I also think hearing their perspective on existing barriers or challenges that make it harder for them or their teams to make inclusion a priority, such as business demands from the firm. 
Also, if there are any other themes that have emerged from the focus groups that we want to ask about, such as the point that Dan brought up about utilization, that is great too. 
I also gave this some thought so sharing some ideas below. 
What personal goals/commitments have you made as it relates to DE&I? Can you share an example of actions that have supported those commitments?
As a leader, how are you holding yourself accountable? How do you hold other leaders and managers on your team accountable?
Where does DE&I fit in with your other business priorities?
Would love thoughts on this one. I think it’s easy to say that DE&I is a priority but actually practicing that is more difficult. I think our focus on utilization is a great example. So I want to ask a question that digs into what DE&I being a priority looks like 
in action
 for these leaders beyond just  “voicing support.” 
From the GM deck: Which processes or policies limit or enhance a culture of inclusion and sense of belonging at FleishmanHillard? What is working or not working?
DE&I Certification Exploratory Conversation: Confirmed for 6/30
 
LMK if there is anything I missed. 
 
Thanks!
Rachel

subject: Fwd: Communities of Practice - Launch Date
body:
Begin forwarded message:
From:
 "The Society for Diversity Inc." <SocietyForDiversity@wildapricot.org>
Date:
 July 27, 2022 at 9:51:08 AM EDT
To:
 Tahitia Timmons <ttimmons73@outlook.com>
Subject:
 
Communities of Practice - Launch Date
Reply-To:
 Amber Martin <ambermartin@societyfordiversity.org>
﻿ 
  
" Communities of practice are made of people with a common interest, who collaborates to do it better."
WHAT IS A COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE?
  
OVERVIEW
A community of practice (CoP) is a group of people who share a common concern, a set of problems, or an interest in a topic and who come together to fulfill both individual and group goals.
Communities of practice often focus on sharing best practices and creating new knowledge to advance a domain of professional practice. 
Many communities of practice rely on face-to-face meetings as well as web-based collaborative environments to communicate, connect and conduct community activities.
 
We are thrilled to announce our Communities of Practice Linked In groups and our Chairs and Co-Chairs for our Communities of Practice. Suppose you are interested in being a part of the community of practice. In that case, this will allow you to form a virtual community depending on the purpose and needs of each individual. 
Our official Communities of Practice launch date will be January 5th, 2023. Currently, the Linked In groups are not visible to the public; we would like all of our members to have first dibs on them.
If you have any questions or concerns, please email 
Ambermartin@societyfordiversity.org.
  
Domain:
 Community members have a shared domain of interest, competence and commitment that distinguishes them from others. This shared domain creates common ground, inspires members to participate, guides their learning, and gives meaning to their actions.
Community
:
Members pursue this interest through joint activities, discussions, problem-solving opportunities, information sharing and relationship building. The notion of a community creates the social fabric for enabling collective learning. A strong community fosters interaction and encourages a willingness to share ideas.
 
Practice:
Community members are actual practitioners in this domain of interest and build a shared repertoire of resources and ideas that they take back to their practice. While the domain provides the general area of interest for the community, the practice is the specific focus around which the community develops, shares and maintains its core of collective knowledge
. 
COMMUNITIES OF PRACTICE GROUPS 
Conference Planning Community (Chair: Jamie Hale, Co-Chair Dr. Danielle Jackman)
Plan the Society for Diversity's 
2022 
Conference, including developing the conference theme; choosing a location; identifying and selecting speakers; recruiting and assigning event day volunteers; assisting with promotions; and more! The conference will focus 
on an opportunity for you to reimagine your resource groups with intentional strategies, fresh insights, and bold ideas. We'll share and discover a game plan for employee participation, ERG/BRG management, recruiting, and more
!
Join Now 
Member News and Recognitions Community (Chair: Maggie Roju, Co-Chair Lea Ann Bowers)
Shine the spotlight on the work of different members monthly, by developing a profile that consists of a brief bio and Q&A. This Community will also report on the accomplishments of members, such as promotions, awards, and other accomplishments.
Join Now 
Advocacy Community (Chair: Harry Petaway, CDE, Tahitia Timmons, CDP)
This Community of Practice will determine how the Society for Diversity can play an important role in changing the future of Equity and Inclusion by providing support for initiatives that will advance the field, including but not limited to ensuring that the role is formally recognized by the U.S. Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS); writing letters of support for/against legislation, court cases, or United Nations (U.N.) efforts; and monitoring global trends in Equity, Diversity and Inclusion.
Join Now 
Careers & Collaborations Community (Chair: Jenn Tardy, CDE, Co-Chair: Taheti Watson)
Offer career advancement tips and advice, as well as help members to navigate through career pitfalls or recover from a setback. This Community can also coordinate opportunities for group meet-ups before/after conferences, or host lunch and learn events at member's offices.
Join Now 
  
D&I Resources Community (Chair: Enid-Mai Jones, Co-Chair: Maritza Guerr
a
)
Identify webinar speakers, write blogs, share events, or suggest books and reports that members should read. This Community of Practice is also responsible for creating member polls and/or identifying resources that Equity, Diversity and Inclusion leaders need to succeed.
Join Now 
This message was sent to you by 
The Society for Diversity Inc.
If you no longer wish to receive these emails, you can 
unsubscribe
 at any time

1-111-111-1111, 
https://societyfordiversity.wildapricot.org/

 Wednesday, July 27, 2022 1:37 PM
To:
 Daniel Gough <d.gough@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Tahitia Timmons <t.timmons@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Hello from Stanley Black & Decker
 
Hello Daniel! 
 
I am a member of the Stanley Black & Decker DEI team and have enjoyed a relationship with LCW since my start date, 12/2020.  Our team has enjoyed a relationship with LCW since 2018.  Two LCW products have reached an extensive SBD audience:  (1) Managing Unconscious Bias 30 minute e-learning for all new hires, and (2) Managing Unconscious Bias in the Workplace 3 hour workshop for all people managers.
 
This past week our Legal team asked for a transcription and associated slides for the Managing Unconscious Bias 30 minute e-learning for all new hires.  I believe due diligence on eLearning content is under review.  It was an urgent request, and we didn’t have anything to share minus the eLearning itself.  I reached out to Tahitia who took the ball with urgency and within 24 hours, delivered on the transcript, and within another business day, a visual document mirroring the eLearning content/graphics.  I know Tahitia had to figure out what teams to go to and had the sense of urgency on her mind – and she delivered.  She asked the right questions, and provided SBD what we needed in a professional and timely manner.  It was an unexpected ask which I am sure put a hiccup in her time.  
 
Tahitia is also doing a lot of thinking regarding the content currency and Train the Trainer design of our 3 hours workshop, which is no longer sustainable for us.  She has great ideas and much depth.  I am impressed!  
 
Too often in a vendor relationship, good work goes unnoticed.  I did not want that to happen.  Tahitia is an asset to LCW!  We are so happy to partner with her.  I hope this makes your day to know it.  
😊
 
Karen
 
Karen Rubano  
 
Global Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Center of Excellence
Stanley Black & Decker
860-304-1228

subject: RE: Hispanic Heritage Event
body:
Hello, 
Do either of you care if for the quiz the bulk of the information for the questions goes in the chat? I was slightly concerned around timing and not feeling like I was speed talking through it.  I am highlighting what I will say out loud the rest would go in the chat.
Would love feedback. 
Thanks
 
0:19 to 0:23 (4 minutes = 3 minutes for quiz + 1 minute for debrief of Q1; note rest of questions debriefed on next slide)
FAC B
OPEN POLL 1: Let’s do a quiz… (FACILITATOR: Quiz/Poll questions are in separate Word document in UTLE folder.)
Debrief q#1 = 1 min
Say: Here’s a pop quiz about facts and history about the Latinx community in the U.S. No googling allowed.
 [Give people 3 minutes to complete quiz.]. 
After everyone is done with quiz, go through and debrief answers 1 by 1.  
Quiz question #1: People whose cultural background or heritage is Latin American prefer to identify as:
The answer is ‘any of the above.’ Different people prefer to identify differently.  
Inoculate the question “Just tell me what to call them” by proactively bringing it up – 
 When in doubt, just ask the person, how do you identify?
Hispanic
 refers to 
language 
– someone with origins in a Spanish speaking country. This includes Spain but not countries like Brazil (Portuguese) or Haiti (Haitian Creole- based largely on French).
 [If anyone asks: Belize (ENG), Guyana (ENG), Suriname (Dutch), and French Guiana (French)]. 
Latino/a
 relates to 
geographic location
 – meaning a person whose country of origin is within Latin America (Central and South America and the Caribbean). This includes people with cultural background in the non-Spanish speaking countries like Brazil.
Latinx
 is being used more and more, especially by younger people, as a gender-neutral word for Latino/a identity. It includes people of any gender or gender identity. 
Chicano
 refers to Mexican-American heritage. It’s also associated with the Mexican-American labor and civil rights movement of the 1960’s and 70’s. For many Mexican Americans, it connotes pride in a shared cultural, ethnic and community identity.
Country of origin:
 Many people prefer to identify not only as Latino or Hispanic, but also or primarily with their country of origin, e.g., as Guatemalan-American, Mexican-American, Venezuelan, or Cuban-American. 
Other: Boricua
 means Puerto Rican – it comes from the indigenous Puerto Ricans’ name for the island: Borikén or Borinquen. 
Spanish
 - Some people call Latinos “Spanish” – but what does Spanish mean? Right, that you’re from Spain.
I will be referring to American residents of Latin American origin interchangeably as Latinx, Latino, and Hispanic.
 
Transition
: 
Okay, let’s move on to q#2, what percent of the population identifies as Latinx? 
MOVE TO NEXT SLIDE TO DEBRIEF Q #2
                LATINX image adapted from: 
https://www.elle.com/culture/career-politics/a38249/latinx-activists-roundtable/
 
 
Debrief remaining questions – provide answer key in a handout to save time
2. Q2: The answer is (e). 
Latinos represent 18.7% of the U.S. population 
or about 62.1 million people (2020 census).
 
Other answers
: 12.4% Black non-Latino, 10.2% two or more races, 6% Asian, 1.1% Am Indian & Alaska Native (
If asked:
 .2% Hawaiian and Pacific Islander and 61.6% white)
.
Source: 
https://www.census.gov/library/visualizations/interactive/race-and-ethnicity-in-the-united-state-2010-and-2020-census.html
Latinos are the largest U.S. minority and the 2nd fastest growing ethnic group (after Asians) in the US. The US Census predicts the Latino pop will reach almost 30% of the population by 2060.
This 
table shows the countries of origin for different Latino groups in the US. 
From the most recent 2020 US Census.
As you can see people of Mexican origin represent the biggest group – 
61.5%
 / 
9.7% 
are Puerto Rican / Salvadoran and Cuban Latinos make up almost 
4% each
 / 
3.4%
 Dominican / 
2.7%
 Guatemalan/ Colombia 2%, Honduras 1.8%
3. [Q5 in UTLE Quiz]. The first European language spoken in what is now the United States was: (a) English, (b) Dutch, (c) Portuguese, 
(d) Spanish,
 (e) French
.
 In 1565 - 
The first permanent European settlement, Saint Augustine, Florida, is established in what is now the U.S. by Spanish admiral Pedro Menéndez de Avilés, 
introducing Catholicism and the Spanish language to the nation
. 
Note that this was 42 years 
before
 the first permanent English settlement, Jamestown, VA, was established 1607.
 
4. [Q7 in UTLE Quiz]. True or 
False:
 About 25% of the 500k-2 million Mexicans deported by the U.S. in the 1930’s were American citizens. 
EXPLAIN: 
In the prework that we have to prepare people for the full 4-hour Cultural Immersion, they have a chance to watch a short video and read some articles that include important history—like this about the mass deportations of Mexicans and Mexican Americans from the U.S., that took place called the 
“Mexican Repatriation” which took place during the Great Depression
 
(1929-36).
The answer is False – the answer is 60%
. (If anyone asks, the vast majority were birthright citizens). Latinos were widely 
blamed for exacerbating the overall economic consequences of the Great Depression.
While supported by the federal government, 
many of the deportations were largely organized and carried out by city and state governments, with support from private companies. For this reason it’s nearly impossible to quantify the exact number of people who were deported.
Transition
: Let’s watch a video to kick off some key historical events for Latinx in the U.S. 
============================================================================
Sources:
https://www.nationalgeographic.com/magazine/2020/07/latinos-hispanic-power-america-immigration-future/
2016 American Community Survey (HISPANIC OR LATINO BY SPECIFIC ORIGIN) - 
https://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/ACS/16_1YR/B03001
)

Hey Tahitia,
I think you know this, but when a client includes legal language in an SOW, I must review & share with our legal partner if needed.
I just reviewed this, and all is pretty standard. 
The only thing I’m concerned about is 8.2 & 8.3:
1.1
             
Service Provider must list all approved subcontractors in Schedule 1 and include any subcontractor's name and location and contact information for the person responsible for privacy and data protection compliance. 
1.2
             
Where the subcontractor fails to fulfill its obligations under such written agreement, Service Provider remains fully liable to Genpact for the subcontractor's performance of its agreement obligations. 
However, in Schedule 1, is says “Approved subcontractors: Not applicable.” I just want to make sure that we are 
not 
using any subcontractors for this – outside/external consultants. Can you please confirm? If we are not, then this is good to go & it can be signed.
 
I notice Alisa’s name at the bottom. Typically, SOW owners sign SOWs. Alisa usually just signs MSAs. But if you want, Alisa can sign it. Not sure if this is a client request. 
It is preferred that the client signs & sends to Alisa electronically for her signature. Alisa should then forward that signed copy to you & me.
LMK if you have any questions.
Thanks!
 
Nicole Barile
Director of Operations
, 
LCW

body:
Thanks Tahitia.
For the first comment, my initial thought was to say “Please note this quote is valid for 30 days,” but I thought that would make the client think that the SOW was good for 30 days. Other suggestions for that wording?
 
And good point about 2 review periods. I was trying to keep this simple, and I know that there can be differences from client to client, so I decided to leave that out. I can be convinced otherwise if people think it’s necessary, but I would say leave it out for now. 
 
Thanks again!

Hi Nicole, 
Thank you for sharing and highlighting the updates. I did have a question about the language  “until signed”  is that too vague – especially for clients who historically have not signed within 30 days. 
For the second bullet did we want to have language included that states additional reviews/edits past that will incur a charge versus assuming that, that is clear to them? 
New language: “Please note this quote is valid for 30 days or 
until signed.”
New language: “All review of content tailoring and/or customization includes 
two (2) rounds of reviews
.” This means that if you deliver something to a client, we are only allowing for 2 rounds of their reviews. If they keep coming back for multiple reviews/edits, that would be additional time charged.
 
Thank you
Tahitia

Hi again everyone.
Apologies in advance for the onslaught of emails, but I want to send one email per topic for clarity’s sake…. (and we have a lot of changes starting at the same time).
 
I’ve mentioned that we have a new SOW starting August 1. I’ll be OOO for a few days, so I have made this change in Compass now.
When you create your SOW PDF in Compass, you will no longer see the options “Licensing Included in SOW” & “Licensing Not Included in SOW.” Instead, you will use 
“SOW 2022” 
for all SOWs going forward.
 
TLDR:
We made this change because we wanted to include the licensing language in all SOWs (makes things simpler as well to have 1 doc)
We have created a new cancelation & postponement policy and have added it to this SOW. There is a new “product” called “Postponement/Cancelation Fee” in Compass. You should use this when charging clients postponement and cancelation fees.
The new SOW includes additional language asking for PO info
The new SOW mentions 25% prepayment & thereafter rolling, monthly invoices at the start of each month
New language: “Please note this quote is valid for 30 days or until signed.”
New language: “All review of content tailoring and/or customization includes two (2) rounds of reviews.” This means that if you deliver something to a client, we are only allowing for 2 rounds of their reviews. If they keep coming back for multiple reviews/edits, that would be additional time charged.
 
Please let me know if you have any questions.
Thank you!
Nicole Barile
Director of Operations
, 
LCW

n.barile@lcwmail.com

body:
Hi Nicole, 
Thank you for sharing and highlighting the updates. I did have a question about the language  “until signed”  is that too vague – especially for clients who historically have not signed within 30 days. 
For the second bullet did we want to have language included that states additional reviews/edits past that will incur a charge versus assuming that, that is clear to them? 
New language: “Please note this quote is valid for 30 days or 
until signed.”
New language: “All review of content tailoring and/or customization includes 
two (2) rounds of reviews
.” This means that if you deliver something to a client, we are only allowing for 2 rounds of their reviews. If they keep coming back for multiple reviews/edits, that would be additional time charged.
 
Thank you
Tahitia
------------------------------------------------------
Tahitia Timmons
(she/her/hers)
Senior Consultant
LCW 
100 S Saunders Rd, Suite 150
Lake Forest, IL 60045

From:
 Nicole Barile <n.barile@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, July 27, 2022 11:25 AM
To:
 Training <training@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Kelly Salek <k.salek@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 New SOW in effect
Importance:
 High
 
Hi again everyone.
Apologies in advance for the onslaught of emails, but I want to send one email per topic for clarity’s sake…. (and we have a lot of changes starting at the same time).
 
I’ve mentioned that we have a new SOW starting August 1. I’ll be OOO for a few days, so I have made this change in Compass now.
When you create your SOW PDF in Compass, you will no longer see the options “Licensing Included in SOW” & “Licensing Not Included in SOW.” Instead, you will use 
“SOW 2022” 
for all SOWs going forward.
 
TLDR:
We made this change because we wanted to include the licensing language in all SOWs (makes things simpler as well to have 1 doc)
We have created a new cancelation & postponement policy and have added it to this SOW. There is a new “product” called “Postponement/Cancelation Fee” in Compass. You should use this when charging clients postponement and cancelation fees.
The new SOW includes additional language asking for PO info
The new SOW mentions 25% prepayment & thereafter rolling, monthly invoices at the start of each month
New language: “Please note this quote is valid for 30 days or until signed.”
New language: “All review of content tailoring and/or customization includes two (2) rounds of reviews.” This means that if you deliver something to a client, we are only allowing for 2 rounds of their reviews. If they keep coming back for multiple reviews/edits, that would be additional time charged.
 
Please let me know if you have any questions.
Thank you!
Nicole Barile
Director of Operations
, 
LCW
Email: 
n.barile@lcwmail.com
Phone: +1 773 888 9294 [EST]

Subject:
 RE: Updates to pricing policies
 
 
Hi Tahitia,
Thanks for sharing.
I already reviewed what they sent, and all is OK. EXCEPT FOR my question to you about subcontractors. See below in yellow. Chuck does not need to review. Policy is that I review with legal’s help if needed. As mentioned, this is all standard language, so legal does not need to review. Our MSA was already reviewed by legal & trumps anything contradictory in the SOW, so we are good to go.
 
Can you please confirm if we will be using subcontractors? If not, then this is OK & ready to sign. 
If we will be using contractors, I would want legal to take a look.
 
As for signature, you can leave Alisa there since you have it already & if that’s what this client has done in the past. 
And here is the process for legal docs 
https://www.dropbox.com/home/PROCESSES%20LIBRARY?preview=Legal+Document+Process_v3+WIP.docx
.
 
Thanks!
 
Nicole Barile
Director of Operations
, 
LCW

Hey Tahitia,
I think you know this, but when a client includes legal language in an SOW, I must review & share with our legal partner if needed.
I just reviewed this, and all is pretty standard. 
The only thing I’m concerned about is 8.2 & 8.3:
1.1
             
Service Provider must list all approved subcontractors in Schedule 1 and include any subcontractor's name and location and contact information for the person responsible for privacy and data protection compliance. 
1.2
             
Where the subcontractor fails to fulfill its obligations under such written agreement, Service Provider remains fully liable to Genpact for the subcontractor's performance of its agreement obligations. 
However, in Schedule 1, is says “Approved subcontractors: Not applicable.” I just want to make sure that we are 
not 
using any subcontractors for this – outside/external consultants. Can you please confirm? If we are not, then this is good to go & it can be signed.
 
I notice Alisa’s name at the bottom. Typically, SOW owners sign SOWs. Alisa usually just signs MSAs. But if you want, Alisa can sign it. Not sure if this is a client request. 
It is preferred that the client signs & sends to Alisa electronically for her signature. Alisa should then forward that signed copy to you & me.
LMK if you have any questions.
Thanks!
 
Nicole Barile
Director of Operations
, 
LCW

I am attaching what I originally sent them on July 14
th
. The document they just sent has additional changes that I have NOT seen prior.  I was attempting to get them moving forward on signing this officially. I would have sent anything with legal language. 
😊
As far as who was listed to sign, I used an MS Word legacy template in their folder as a guide and put Alisa instead of Randy. I am happy to do whatever the standard practice is. 
I want to approach this tactfully. Can I write back and state we will review their additions/revisions and get back to them or would you or Chuck prefer to do that? 
Thanks
Tahitia

Subject:
 FW: Updates to pricing policies
 
Hey Tahitia,
I think you know this, but when a client includes legal language in an SOW, I must review & share with our legal partner if needed.
I just reviewed this, and all is pretty standard. 
The only thing I’m concerned about is 8.2 & 8.3:
1.1
                
Service Provider must list all approved subcontractors in Schedule 1 and include any subcontractor's name and location and contact information for the person responsible for privacy and data protection compliance. 
1.2
                
Where the subcontractor fails to fulfill its obligations under such written agreement, Service Provider remains fully liable to Genpact for the subcontractor's performance of its agreement obligations. 
However, in Schedule 1, is says “Approved subcontractors: Not applicable.” I just want to make sure that we are 
not 
using any subcontractors for this – outside/external consultants. Can you please confirm? If we are not, then this is good to go & it can be signed.
 
I notice Alisa’s name at the bottom. Typically, SOW owners sign SOWs. Alisa usually just signs MSAs. But if you want, Alisa can sign it. Not sure if this is a client request. 
It is preferred that the client signs & sends to Alisa electronically for her signature. Alisa should then forward that signed copy to you & me.
LMK if you have any questions.
Thanks!
 
Nicole Barile
Director of Operations
, 
LCW

subject: FW: Prepayment Process
body:
Good morning!
Attached is what Grace sent me. This is really more about correcting my prepayment process than it is creating an outline/template for us going forward 
😊
.
That said, she does include sections like “application”, “resources”, etc., which are helpful, but I think it overcomplicates things. It’s written more like an SOP doc & not a simple process doc.
 
Any thoughts? 
Thank you!
 
Nicole Barile
Director of Operations
, 
LCW
 
From:
 Grace Vottero <g.vottero@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, July 26, 2022 6:26 PM
To:
 Nicole Barile <n.barile@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Prepayment Process
 
Hey Nicole
 
See attached my edited version of the prepayment process. This is just the process, not the flowchart, which I’m able to generate now but wanted to sync with you to make sure this was headed in a direction you liked.
 
I’ve also not formatted the document yet, but if you don’t mind, once you like the process and Tahitia weighs in, I’d be happy to quickly spruce it up just a little bit (max. 15 minutes of sprucing).
 
Let me know if you want to talk or how I can help next steps.
 
This was fun for me, thanks!
 
Grace

 unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. If you believe the content of this email may be unsafe, please forward it as an attachment to 
thislooksphishy@genpact.com
 or use the 'This Looks Phishy' Outlook button.
Hello, 
I am reaching out to clients who may have unsigned SOWs in process. Beginning 
August 1, 2022,
 LCW will be increasing prices and requiring a 25% deposit on all SOWs. 
We highly encourage clients with unsigned SOWs to sign and return them before these changes take effect. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to ask. 
Thank you and we look forward to continued success and collaboration in the future. 
 
------------------------------------------------------
Tahitia Timmons
(she/her/hers)
Senior Consultant
LCW 
100 S Saunders Rd, Suite 150
Lake Forest, IL 60045
  
 
 
(
Ask me how we helped the #1 organization on 
Forbes Best Employers for Diversity 2022 list with their diversity journey.)

From:

c.adams@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, July 19, 2022 12:00 PM
To:
 Office <
office@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Staff Announcement
 
Team -
 
We wanted to inform you all that Tahitia Timmons is resigning her position at LCW, effective
 end of 
August.
 
While we hate seeing Tahitia leave LCW we are thrilled for her reasoning – she has decided to start her own consulting company to focus on her personal and professional passion: Health Equity. We could not be happier for Tahitia’s next chapter.
 
The few months that Tahitia has been with LCW have been wonderful, and too short. She freely offered her unique perspective and her deep expertise internally and performed with considerable aplomb with our clients. She is knowledgeable, unflappable, and sharing. She contributed to our success by challenging the status quo and offering potential solutions based on her broad experiences in the field. She never critiqued a process or approach without also offering a different perspective as a way forward. That was always greatly appreciated.
 
Tahitia will spend the next few weeks transitioning her work. More information will follow.
 
Alisa and I wish Tahitia the very best and are happy that her circumstances have presented her with this amazing opportunity, and we strongly support her striking out on her own. Please join us in congratulating Tahitia on this exciting move.
 
Best,
 
Alisa/Chuck
 
 
______________________________________
Chuck Adams

Lake Forest, IL 60045 USA

Karen Rubano

 Re: Congratulations! 
 
Thank you for message. I’m finalizing my handoff thoughts and JTI will be a client that would need some support. I believe they may have an additional 3-4 engagements plus the 3 in the fall. I have you listed as the AC for them and as soon as I get the ok I’ll meet with the consultant I’m handing them off to and you for an update. Then I’ll introduce the new team to Edward. From:
 Nassise Geleta <
n.geleta@lcwmail.com
>
Sent:
 Friday, July 22, 2022 3:19:30 PM
To:
 Tahitia Timmons <
t.timmons@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Congratulations! 
 
Hi Tahitia, 
 
Happy Friday! Hope you are well. 
😊
 Congratulations on starting your own firm. I’m sad we won’t get to work together for long, but so excited for you to start this endeavor. There’s lots to be done in the realm of Health Equity and I wish you the best of luck b/c we certainly need people who get it to lead the charge as it quite literally is a matter of life and death for so many folks! Again, let me know if I can be of help with JTI—especially as you offload your clients and step into this transitionary period. Have a great weekend! 
 
Warmly, 
 
Nassise

body:
Hello, 
 
I wanted to check in with you regarding which LCW offerings your organization might be considering for Q3 and Q4 of 2022 and Q1 of 2023. 
Enclosed you will find our mini-workshops along with our e-Learning and micro-learning modules catalog. Our e-Learnings are a great way to provide ongoing support and education regarding Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion. Please let me know if you are interested in pricing for any of these or would like to schedule a time to discuss this in greater detail. 
Looking forward to hearing from you. 
Tahitia

subject: Re: Congratulations!
body:
Thank you for message. I’m finalizing my handoff thoughts and JTI will be a client that would need some support. I believe they may have an additional 3-4 engagements plus the 3 in the fall. I have you listed as the AC for them and as soon as I get the ok I’ll meet with the consultant I’m handing them off to and you for an update. Then I’ll introduce the new team to Edward. It should be pretty smooth, they’re a great motivated group and have had a good working relationship with LCW. 
Thanks again I will keep you posted.
Tahitia

It’s Colleen here, your Head of Community at Miro. 👋
Are you ready to meet and work with collaborators from all over the world? 
Let’s connect
, learn, and grow together — and have fun while doing it!
Explore the Miro Community →
 
 
What’s in it for you:
•
Get advice
 from fellow community members and solve challenges together.
•
Start from experience.
 There are over 1,000 templates with proven workflows and frameworks made by the Miro community that await you in Miroverse.
•
Find your people. 
Connect and share best practices with other builders, facilitators, and designers.
•
Access special events
 with thought leaders, creators, and experts, just for the Miro Community.
•
Plus, more exciting opportunities to connect, learn, and inspire great things together!
 
Happy collaborating,
Colleen Curtis
