adrianne.smith@fleishman.com
>
Subject:
 Our call today
 
Hi team, 
 
Adrianne is in Cannes this week, and I only have a few items on my list, so I was thinking we could share updates via email this week.  
 
LMK if that works for you, or if there was something specific you wanted to discuss today. 
 
In the meantime, below is what I have on my radar. 
Focus Groups
EMEA
: Confirmed and on the calendar for 7/6.
APAC:
 Waiting to hear back from the facilitator about additional times for July. 
US API:
 Waiting to hear back from the facilitator. At this point Thursday, 7/7: 11am-12pm CT is probably the best option so let me know if I should look at the second/third weeks of July too. 
1:1 Stakeholder Interviews
Scheduling
: LCW working on time blocks. I also have a meeting with Lisa Moehlenkamp tomorrow to give her a heads up that we’re starting to schedule. 
Questions:
 FH/LCW to finalize questions. 
I know your team is working on those based on our conversation last week. 
To Adrianne’s point on the call, we think there are three “themes” to these conversations: Personal commitment, accountability (for themselves and others) and I also think hearing their perspective on existing barriers or challenges that make it harder for them or their teams to make inclusion a priority, such as business demands from the firm. 
Also, if there are any other themes that have emerged from the focus groups that we want to ask about, such as the point that Dan brought up about utilization, that is great too. 
I also gave this some thought so sharing some ideas below. 
What personal goals/commitments have you made as it relates to DE&I? Can you share an example of actions that have supported those commitments?
As a leader, how are you holding yourself accountable? How do you hold other leaders and managers on your team accountable?
Where does DE&I fit in with your other business priorities?
Would love thoughts on this one. I think it’s easy to say that DE&I is a priority but actually practicing that is more difficult. I think our focus on utilization is a great example. So I want to ask a question that digs into what DE&I being a priority looks like 
in action
 for these leaders beyond just  “voicing support.” 
From the GM deck: Which processes or policies limit or enhance a culture of inclusion and sense of belonging at FleishmanHillard? What is working or not working?
DE&I Certification Exploratory Conversation: Confirmed for 6/30
 
LMK if there is anything I missed. 
 
Thanks!
Rachel

subject: Congratulations!
body:
Hi Tahitia, 
 
Happy Friday! Hope you are well. 
😊
 Congratulations on starting your own firm. I’m sad we won’t get to work together for long, but so excited for you to start this endeavor. There’s lots to be done in the realm of Health Equity and I wish you the best of luck b/c we certainly need people who get it to lead the charge as it quite literally is a matter of life and death for so many folks! Again, let me know if I can be of help with JTI—especially as you offload your clients and step into this transitionary period. Have a great weekend! 
 
Warmly, 
 
Nassise

subject: IDI Debrief Shadowing
body:
Hi Tahitia, 
I hope you are doing well. Happy Friday!!! 
😊And I just wanted to say I really enjoyed talking with you the other day. It turned into a life coaching session that I greatly needed. You helped me to figure out what I really want to do with my career. I hope that we can stay in touch. 
I was just in a meeting talking about IDI stuff. Conner mentioned that you would like to observe Jeffrey doing a few 1:1 IDI debriefs? If so, I will start to contact the participants/client to see if they are okay with someone shadowing. 
Thanks,
Kaitlin

subject: Promised deliverables
body:
Hi Edward, 
Great discussion today!
Attached is a proposed quote which can always be modified. I included the facilitated learnings we discussed and three micro learnings with pricing. As I mentioned they are moving away from the current eLearning model toward an LMS (soft launch end of Q4). I have these at 25 users and 6 months (they are not doing 12 months).  There were also price increases since the list you shared and I cannot override them BUT I was able to still have the 25% show up, however that is contingent on the prepay and 4+ and will no longer be available moving forward
I am also enclosing a link to a zip folder with pdfs of the facilitated titles we discussed. 
That is available here 
https://www.dropbox.com/l/AACk8tB0EdaazCqPPmltk1-8gcXTHuk8WVs
Please let me know that this opens and is viewable. 
Hopefully this will assist you when you meet with the group on Monday. 
Thanks and have a great weekend!
 
Tahitia

Subject:
 DHR Exec Sponsorship Program & LCW 
 
Hi Nicole,
 
Per our meeting last Friday, I have moved forward with contacting Charles (Chuck) Adams at LCW, Redhouse's most trusted partner in all things DEI.   I have worked with Chuck and many others at the firm for over 12 years!  Furthermore, several LCW virtual DEI trainings are in Danaher's online library.
 
LCW has agreed to take the lead in the design and execution of session 3 for the Black Asso. Exec Sponsorship Program.   I also requested LCW’s assistance in providing meaningful content and facilitation for session 2 of the Latin X Executive Sponsorship Program (BTW-  It took considerable effort to convince Jason, that LCW is needed to deliver a meaningful and believable Latin X program for the sponsors.)  My email (attached below) also mentions the possibility of providing executive coaching and support.
 
Chuck is included on this email and will reach out to you separately to ensure that his team is aligned with your understanding and expectations.   Given that I/Redhouse will be pausing operations for 6-8 weeks, I recommended that LCW prepare a brief proposal and execute an agreement/statement of work directly with Danaher Corp D+I.   Hoping LCW’s previous extensive work with Corporate D+I will help make the contracting process move quickly.
 
I will leave it to the two of you to correct and realign the understanding as needed.  I know that I’m passing the baton on these projects to a team who will deliver with excellence.  
 
Best regards,
Arlene F. Roane (She/Her)
Creating spaces where people BELIEVE they are valued and appreciated.
Redhouse Performance Consulting, LLC
www.redhousepc.com
 
Mobile US 1.513.290.6569
 
 
 
 
 
From:
 Arlene Roane 
Sent:
 Monday, June 27, 2022 8:39 AM
To:
 'Chuck Adams' <
c.adams@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Danaher Corp D+I Projects 
 
Hello Chuck,
 
Hope your summer is off to a good start. 
 
I’m reaching out to request your assistance and leadership on several initiatives with Danaher Corp D+I.  I am scheduled to have major surgery on July 13
th
 and would be greatly relieved and encouraged if LCW/you were to step in.   I have already received approval from the CDO, Nicole Wormley.  The projects include:
 
Black Associate Executive Sponsorship Program – This program was initiated in 3Q2021.  Redhouse/I designed and led the executive sponsors thru a process that included the IDI/1x1 in-depth briefings and 2 group learning sessions exploring the significant cultural and day-to-day experiences of Blacks in corporate roles.  Developing and anchoring a panel discussion with Danaher Board Member Shane Sanders and a Black Female Executive (TBD).  LCW can take the lead or we could collaborate on recruiting the Black female.  The target delivery is mid/late 3Q.  The program format can be a hybrid live/virtual.  You and at least one panelist is live; the other panelist(s) can have interviews pre-recorded.  The target audience are Danaher’s senior executive leadership team members who are actively sponsoring mid-career Black executives.  
 
Latin X Executive Sponsorship Program – This program is being initiated now and is intended to follow the same trajectory as the Black Exec Sponsorship Prgm (ESP).  The Sr. Dir Corp D+I (a Black male) is responsible needs assistance in finding and delivering content similar to what was presented in the Black ESP.   LCW’s depth and breadth of content and experienced facilitation is sorely needed.  Target delivery is early to mid 3Q
 
Additionally,  Nicole (the CDO) would like to discuss the possibility of having you (or another Black male) provide executive coaching for the Sr. Director Corp D+I.  I can share more about this when we talk.   I will also brief you on other Redhouse projects at Danaher.  While ultimately I anticipate recovering and getting back to full engagement by  early 4Q, I need to prepare for the possibility of a longer recouperation.
 
I am hoping that we can find time to meet this week. I am available any day EXCEPT Wednesday.  I will be infinitely flexible including early mornings and evenings.  
 
Thank you in advance.
 
Best regards,
Arlene F. Roane (She/Her)
Creating spaces where people BELIEVE they are valued and appreciated.
Redhouse Performance Consulting, LLC
www.redhousepc.com
 
Mobile US 1.513.290.6569

Subject:
 Language change request in Progressive SOW
 
Hi Nicole,
Progressive has requested some language changes to existing content they previously purchased. In the original purchase the language regarding recording, video is not in their agreement. They would like this bullet removed on the attached SOW, they will not sign if it is in there. They stated they would not have an issue if that language was in a new agreement but that this language feels like it would be an addendum to the existing agreement. 
Can you remove the second bullet under key assumptions that reads: 
Video, recording, duplication, copying, adaptation, and distribution of any program and/or materials provided by LCW is prohibited, unless written permission is provided. 
Kelly and I feel Progressive has the potential to be a large client next year and they have indicated they are interested in replacing their DEI content and adding even more to their program. 
I am also happy to meet and chat if you need further details. 
Thank you
Tahitia

Good day Tahitia and Marisa - 
In addition to the information below, there are a few things that needs attention: 
 
Module 2: Managing w/Intercultural Competence
Slide 5
…Being that the suggested text not only appears onscreen, but every example (words in the quotes) does have the audio narrated. If we change this one, we will either need to have the voiceover talent rerecord (need to find out availability and cost) or we can remove all the audio pieces from the IDI interaction slides? 
Thoughts?
  
I believe removing the voice over from all is the best way to go.
 
Slide 5: Was this the suggested text we talked about:
It makes no difference to me if my 
teammates 
have cultural differences 
she is from the North or the South, single, married or divorced, thin or fat, black or white, or what religion she belongs to. She’s one of us, and
 
as long as we 
let her know that, we 
can all work together.  
That could work, or here’s what we’ve used elsewhere: “My team members’ cultural backgrounds don’t make any difference to me. We’re part of the same team working toward the same business goals, and that’s all we need to work well together”  
 
 
On 
slide 6
, here is what I have written down…
Men and women often
 
Employees
 People 
may analyze issues 
differently
 and communicate about them differently.  I think a group can be more creative if these differences are put to good use.
 (intercultural)  
I would just use “people” vs “employees”.  We can also remove the extra “differently”
 
Module 5: Evaluating Talent
For the slide that references Kochman’s work is the one shown below. If we change out the references, I do believe that we will also need to exclude or cut the red-marked audio as well. Please advise.   
Yes, I agree.

Hello Marisa, 
Thank you for meeting with the team last week. As a newer consultant here at LCW I really appreciated learning about the relationship Progressive and LCW built along with your successes.  Kudos on being named #1 on Forbes list of America’s Best Employers for Diversity 2022! Interesting fact, LCW has worked with 2 of the 5 top companies on the list.
Would you be able to reply to the areas highlighted in the table? Our goal is to have this done quickly, we are tentatively hoping by end of next week. 
I am off but will be monitoring emails as I know this is something your group would like to get completed ASAP. I will also be sending over an estimated quote/sow for the work by tomorrow. 
Thank you 
Tahitia
 
Module
Concern
Suggested change/recommendations
Managing with Intercultural Competence
Slide 5 - intercultural development continuum: Minimization example - "It makes no difference to me if she's from the North or the South, single, married or divorced, black or white, or what religion she belongs to" 
The Progressive Team will share the language that they have used in other areas with the LCW team.

Managing with Intercultural Competence

Evaluating Talent
Page 13: Insight highlights Thomas Kochman’s work on “Black and White Styles in Conflict,” – based on his research, Kochman states that “black and white Americans use two different communication styles for establishing the same goal of trust in communication: truth over peace and peace over truth.”  
It is part of the voiceover, and when the insight is clicked this shows
LCW checking for replacement references
LCW will update with new text and audio as needed
*Marisa were there any concerns regarding the second reference which is about gender difference? We can look for a replacement there too if that would be helpful.
  
Good catch, yes, probably so.  If you can look at alternatives, that would be great
Providing Opportunity
Page 11: 
2nd example– “When we hear dissent from someone from a different race, it provokes more thought than when it comes from someone of our race.” - article citation from Scientific American, “How Diversity Made Us Smarter.” Oct. 2014.   
 
4th example: “The groups with racial diversity significantly outperformed the group with no racial diversity. Being with similar people leads us to think we all hold the same information and share the same perspective. This perspective, which stopped the all-white groups from effectively processing the information, is what hinders creativity and innovation. This is a great reminder as we look for ways to promote from within or staff our teams.” –“Surface level diversity and decision-making in groups: when does deep level similarity help?”
LCW checking for replacement references
LCW will update with new text and audio as needed

Subject:
 LCW Training Solutions & Pricing 
 
WARNING: This is an EXTERNAL email.
 Do not open attachments or click links unless you know the email address is valid!
 
Hi Edward, 
 
Here is pricing overview for a variety of multi-modal training solutions. I have also attached a pdf with snapshots of each title for reference and preview links. It has been updated to include information for the Intercultural Development Inventory as an additional strategic training solution.
 
eLearning
Each module includes content, quizzes, short writing activities, and other exercises that allow each learner to pause, reflect, and practice inclusive behaviors right at their computer.
For all audiences:
Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias
Foundations of Diversity & Inclusion
Culture & Identity
Fostering Collaboration
For managers & leaders:
Managing with Intercultural Competence
Evaluating Talent Inclusively
Hiring & Promoting Top Talent
Practicing Inclusion
Embedding Inclusion
 
PRICING OPTIONS
“Per User License” - $50/user. Made available for a certain period (i.e., 6-12 months - not perpetual). Courses would be hosted on ScormCloud. Users may take any available language version of the course.
“Site License” – Each module $60,000 (bundle pricing of $45,000 per module if ordering 3 or more modules)
 
Microlearning
: Unconscious bias series
Offer quick reinforcements for participants to access at the point of decision or needed action.
 
Managing unconscious bias in 
recruiting
Managing unconscious bias in
 interviewing
Managing Unconscious Bias in 
hiring
Managing Unconscious Bias in 
performance reviews
Managing Unconscious Bias in 
talent review

“Site License” – Each module $15,000 (bundle pricing of $11,500 per module if ordering 3 or more videos)
 
Facilitated learning:
 (for up to 50 seats per session)
For all audiences
Managing Unconscious Bias in the Workplace - $5,500 per session
Building a Culture of Inclusion - $15,000 per session
How to have difficult conversations on race – $5,500
The Power of Allyship - $5,500
POC Coaching Clinic - $15,000 per cohort
For managers & leaders
Building a Culture of Inclusion - $15,000 per session
Managing Bias in Recruiting - $5,500
Managing Bias in Hiring - $5,500
Managing Bias in Talent Acquisition - $15,000 per session
Understanding Microaggressions - $5,500 per session
 
Intercultural Development Inventory (IDI assessment & coaching)
Assessment administration per participant - $150
Individual coaching - $450
2-hour virtual group debrief - $5,500
 
Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns.
 
Looking forward to your thoughts.
 
Warm regards,

subject: Discussion: The Transfer of Your Clients
body:
Happy Friday!
 
Hoping you’re having a great day! The other day you started sharing the companies you think I should take when you leave. Can you provide that list? I was walking the dog when we spoke. I want to put my claim in before others start grabbing. 
 
You mentioned Clariant, Moog…anything else? I wasn’t in the right headspace when we spoke…frustrated with the lack of process but I know I must be strategic. On another note, that frustration was noted by Kelly and she and her team are working on processes. I can appreciate change for the better. 
 
So please tell me your recommendations. I feel like a vulture circling from above. 
😊
 
 
Thanks!
 
------------------------------------------------------
Melonya Johnson
Consultant (Buffalo, NY)
P: 773.938.4157

subject: Accepted: Please review - Progressive edits and meeting request
Language change request in Progressive SOW
body:
Hi Nicole,
Progressive has requested some language changes to existing content they previously purchased. In the original purchase the language regarding recording, video is not in their agreement. They would like this bullet removed on the attached SOW, they will not sign if it is in there. They stated they would not have an issue if that language was in a new agreement but that this language feels like it would be an addendum to the existing agreement. 
Can you remove the second bullet under key assumptions that reads: 
Video, recording, duplication, copying, adaptation, and distribution of any program and/or materials provided by LCW is prohibited, unless written permission is provided. 
Kelly and I feel Progressive has the potential to be a large client next year and they have indicated they are interested in replacing their DEI content and adding even more to their program. 
I am also happy to meet and chat if you need further details. 
Thank you
Tahitia

SOW with license is for things like e-learning, microlearning, etc.
SOW without license is for facilitations only (no licensing).
Proposal is for just giving a client idea of pricing and programming, but no one signs that so it’s not binding. I’ve used it when a client wants to see all of our mini workshops or wants to know what immersions we have with pricing.

Would you use the SOW without licensing for an elearning update  (they updated a few slides on activities they already licensed) or does that language about licensing have to be there still?

To:
 Tahitia Timmons <t.timmons@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Compass PDF differences
 
Hi.
SOW with license is for things like e-learning, microlearning, etc.
SOW without license is for facilitations only (no licensing).
Proposal is for just giving a client idea of pricing and programming, but no one signs that so it’s not binding. I’ve used it when a client wants to see all of our mini workshops or wants to know what immersions we have with pricing. 
 
Does that help?
 
If you hit the PDF button & read through, you can see more, especially regarding licenses.
 
Starting Aug 1, we will use the SOW 2022 one.
 
Nicole Barile
Director of Operations
, 
LCW

Subject: 
Staff Announcement
 
Team -
 
We wanted to inform you all that Tahitia Timmons is resigning her position at LCW, effective
 end of 
August.
 
While we hate seeing Tahitia leave LCW we are thrilled for her reasoning – she has decided to start her own consulting company to focus on her personal and professional passion: Health Equity. We could not be happier for Tahitia’s next chapter.
 
The few months that Tahitia has been with LCW have been wonderful, and too short. She freely offered her unique perspective and her deep expertise internally and performed with considerable aplomb with our clients. She is knowledgeable, unflappable, and sharing. She contributed to our success by challenging the status quo and offering potential solutions based on her broad experiences in the field. She never critiqued a process or approach without also offering a different perspective as a way forward. That was always greatly appreciated.
 
Tahitia will spend the next few weeks transitioning her work. More information will follow.
 
Alisa and I wish Tahitia the very best and are happy that her circumstances have presented her with this amazing opportunity, and we strongly support her striking out on her own. Please join us in congratulating Tahitia on this exciting move.
 
Best,
 
Alisa/Chuck
 
 
______________________________________

I am sure they will tell us more  once they get what they need. 
Thanks

Subject:
 Clariant Recommendations - Global Leadership Team
 
Dear Isabelle,
 
We've spent a great deal of time reviewing our notes from our earlier conversations and the RFP documents. Upon review, it became clear that your shift in focus is an opportunity for LCW to craft a 
bespoke
 learning journey that will address individual leadership development needs and engage your Global Leadership Team to take measurable actions towards Clariant's desire to build a sustainable culture of inclusion. This approach will build self-awareness, create mutual understanding around inclusive leadership, and support DEI strategy and accountability. LCW is pleased to present the following recommendations:
 
IDI Individual Assessments & Individual Debriefs - $47,500
8-Hour Inclusive Leadership Program
 
- $105,000*
LCW will leverage our proven senior leader agendas as a starting place to tailor material and co-create an upskilling journey that makes Clariant leaders feel more confident, comfortable, and knowledgeable on the subject and equips them to act as true advocates and champions. LCW recommends that all participants take the IDI ® Assessment and receive the group IDI ® debrief results during the Leadership Training Program. Participants will receive individualized results after the facilitated training to prepare for and align with the Leadership Coaching Clinic.
2 Sessions - Virtual
25 Participants per session
Includes Group IDI Debrief
Leadership Coaching Clinic – $80,000*
During this 
bespoke
 program, LCW will work with your Global Leadership Team to explore the role your executives and senior leaders must play to build a sustainable culture of inclusion. The coaching clinic will support your leadership team in individual and personalized development journeys. Participants will work to identify areas of upskilling and choose areas of focus by selecting from a list of curricula, which LCW will tailor to meet the Global Leadership Team's needs. For example, group coaching sessions may focus on gender or perhaps microaggressions. 
Four Cohorts
Eight weeks (4 sessions every other week) - Virtual
Four 
1-2 hour
 sessions
Accountability Partners
Four growth assignments
Bespoke
 Action Planning Workshop – $33,500*
Using the IDI ® and the Leadership Coaching Clinic as the framework, LCW will guide the Global Leadership Team through exercises that include reflection, commitment, and accountability. This session will align with Clariant's diversity, equity, and inclusion roadmap, which revolves around the following pillars Leadership Commitment, Building a Culture of Inclusion, Gender Equality, and Cultural Identity. Participants will leave the session with commitments to action items that support these initiatives, along with an understanding of the amount of effort required and the potential impacts of these efforts. It will also include 
goal-setting
 and expectations. 
2-Hour Session - Virtual
2-Facilitators
Incorporates Growth Assignments from Coaching Clinic
Hyper-focused on Individual Leadership Action Planning and Strategic Planning
 
*The pricing reflects LCW's customization and revisions 
rates
 and consulting hours associated with the Scope of Work. Additional consulting hours are billed at an hourly rate. LCW commits to obtaining Clariant's approval before the start of work outlined in the agreement.
 
In addition to the abovementioned costs, LCW will charge a 
10% Project Management Fee. 
 
LCW's eagerness to partner with you on this journey has not waivered. We would welcome the opportunity to discuss these recommendations in more detail and answer any questions you might have. We are confident that our deep understanding of how to increase cultural awareness and strategic vision related to diversity and inclusion will help Clariant achieve the goals laid out before the organization.
 
As always, we are grateful for your continued consideration and are ready to begin work immediately.
 
Kind regards,
 
Melissa

Good day Tahitia and Marisa - 
In addition to the information below, there are a few things that needs attention: 
 
Module 2: Managing w/Intercultural Competence
Slide 5
…Being that the suggested text not only appears onscreen, but every example (words in the quotes) does have the audio narrated. If we change this one, we will either need to have the voiceover talent rerecord (need to find out availability and cost) or we can remove all the audio pieces from the IDI interaction slides? 
Thoughts?
  
I believe removing the voice over from all is the best way to go.
 
Slide 5: Was this the suggested text we talked about:
It makes no difference to me if my 
teammates 
have cultural differences 
she is from the North or the South, single, married or divorced, thin or fat, black or white, or what religion she belongs to. She’s one of us, and
 
as long as we 
let her know that, we 
can all work together.  
That could work, or here’s what we’ve used elsewhere: “My team members’ cultural backgrounds don’t make any difference to me. We’re part of the same team working toward the same business goals, and that’s all we need to work well together”  
 
 
On 
slide 6
, here is what I have written down…
Men and women often
 
Employees
 People 
may analyze issues 
differently
 and communicate about them differently.  I think a group can be more creative if these differences are put to good use.
 (intercultural)  
I would just use “people” vs “employees”.  We can also remove the extra “differently”
 
Module 5: Evaluating Talent
For the slide that references Kochman’s work is the one shown below. If we change out the references, I do believe that we will also need to exclude or cut the red-marked audio as well. Please advise.   
Yes, I agree.

Hello Marisa, 
Thank you for meeting with the team last week. As a newer consultant here at LCW I really appreciated learning about the relationship Progressive and LCW built along with your successes.  Kudos on being named #1 on Forbes list of America’s Best Employers for Diversity 2022! Interesting fact, LCW has worked with 2 of the 5 top companies on the list.
Would you be able to reply to the areas highlighted in the table? Our goal is to have this done quickly, we are tentatively hoping by end of next week. 
I am off but will be monitoring emails as I know this is something your group would like to get completed ASAP. I will also be sending over an estimated quote/sow for the work by tomorrow. 
Thank you 
Tahitia
 
Module
Concern
Suggested change/recommendations
Managing with Intercultural Competence
Slide 5 - intercultural development continuum: Minimization example - "It makes no difference to me if she's from the North or the South, single, married or divorced, black or white, or what religion she belongs to" 
The Progressive Team will share the language that they have used in other areas with the LCW team.
 
See above suggestion
Managing with Intercultural Competence
Slide 6:  "Men and women often analyze issues differently and communicate about them differently.  I think a group can be more creative if these differences are put to good use"
The Progressive Team will share the language that they have used in other areas with the LCW team.
  
See above suggestion
Evaluating Talent
Page 13: Insight highlights Thomas Kochman’s work on “Black and White Styles in Conflict,” – based on his research, Kochman states that “black and white Americans use two different communication styles for establishing the same goal of trust in communication: truth over peace and peace over truth.”  
It is part of the voiceover, and when the insight is clicked this shows
LCW checking for replacement references
LCW will update with new text and audio as needed
*Marisa were there any concerns regarding the second reference which is about gender difference? We can look for a replacement there too if that would be helpful.
  
Good catch, yes, probably so.  If you can look at alternatives, that would be great
Providing Opportunity
Page 11: 
2nd example– “When we hear dissent from someone from a different race, it provokes more thought than when it comes from someone of our race.” - article citation from Scientific American, “How Diversity Made Us Smarter.” Oct. 2014.   
 
4th example: “The groups with racial diversity significantly outperformed the group with no racial diversity. Being with similar people leads us to think we all hold the same information and share the same perspective. This perspective, which stopped the all-white groups from effectively processing the information, is what hinders creativity and innovation. This is a great reminder as we look for ways to promote from within or staff our teams.” –“Surface level diversity and decision-making in groups: when does deep level similarity help?”
LCW checking for replacement references
LCW will update with new text and audio as needed

subject: RE: PPT backgrounds/template/layout question
body:
Thanks Sarah! I got the answer. I had been doing a walk through with a client and showed two items that are currently in the navy opening screen and the client asked if it was possible to have the lighter look and feel and show who the presenters which when of course can do. However I wondered if there was a standard layout or push to use a specific template. 
Appreciate all who shared thoughts – I have the answer.

From:

Sent:
 Thursday, July 21, 2022 1:44 PM
To:
 Tahitia Timmons <t.timmons@lcwmail.com>; Training <training@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: PPT backgrounds/template/layout question
 
Hi Tahitia – replying all in case it is useful for folks. 
 
We have two templates, the “hot” and “cool” colors (blue and brown), each one does have a number of standard design layouts 
We have the predesigned slides that are in Training 
à
 Design Assets 
à
 Predesigned Slides -new
We do NOT have a standard way that slide decks are put together (or content guide), as you outlined below. While certainly every training has all the elements you list, we don’t have a list of those anywhere (to my knowledge)
Depending on what program it is, you might find a content summary for that particular program in the sales deck (it consists of 2 slides, one with a program description and the learning outcomes, and a second with a summary of the content). 
 
Hope that helps 
😊

subject: RE: Post conversation follow-up
body:
Hi Tahitia,
 
My apologies for the delay on the SOW.  I was looking at it and noticed that there’s new legal language in it that was not in our original contract nor in the prior SOW from 2020. I’d like to talk this through with you tomorrow. 
 
Overall, I think the changes look good with maybe a couple of minor nuances for our environment.  
 
I look forward to catching up tomorrow!
 
From:
 Tahitia Timmons <t.timmons@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Thursday, July 14, 2022 8:03 AM
To:
 Marisa Afzali <Marisa_Afzali@Progressive.com>
Cc:
 Kelly Salek <k.salek@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 [EXTERNAL] RE: Post conversation follow-up
 
Hi Marisa, 
No need to apologize traveling can be rough, especially now. I have attached an SOW proposal  (Quote No. 202227) for the work. Once we have that signed off, we can begin formal work on the changes. However, in good faith we have started aspects of this project. We also anticipate having this finalized by early next week now with a draft available to review first. Once I have the signed SOW I can start building those first draft changes. 
What type of availability do you have next week to run through a first draft? 
Thank you 
Tahitia

Subject:
 [EXTERNAL] RE: Post conversation follow-up
 
Good day Tahitia and Marisa - 
In addition to the information below, there are a few things that needs attention: 
 
Module 2: Managing w/Intercultural Competence
Slide 5
…Being that the suggested text not only appears onscreen, but every example (words in the quotes) does have the audio narrated. If we change this one, we will either need to have the voiceover talent rerecord (need to find out availability and cost) or we can remove all the audio pieces from the IDI interaction slides? 
Thoughts?
  
I believe removing the voice over from all is the best way to go.
 
Slide 5: Was this the suggested text we talked about:
It makes no difference to me if my 
teammates 
have cultural differences 
she is from the North or the South, single, married or divorced, thin or fat, black or white, or what religion she belongs to. She’s one of us, and
 
as long as we 
let her know that, we 
can all work together.  
That could work, or here’s what we’ve used elsewhere: “My team members’ cultural backgrounds don’t make any difference to me. We’re part of the same team working toward the same business goals, and that’s all we need to work well together”  
 
 
On 
slide 6
, here is what I have written down…
Men and women often
 
Employees
 People 
may analyze issues 
differently
 and communicate about them differently.  I think a group can be more creative if these differences are put to good use.
 (intercultural)  
I would just use “people” vs “employees”.  We can also remove the extra “differently”
 
Module 5: Evaluating Talent
For the slide that references Kochman’s work is the one shown below. If we change out the references, I do believe that we will also need to exclude or cut the red-marked audio as well. Please advise.   
Yes, I agree.
 
 
From:
 Tahitia Timmons <
t.timmons@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Monday, July 11, 2022 11:06 AM
To:
 
Marisa_Afzali@Progressive.com
Cc:
 Kelly Salek <
k.salek@lcwmail.com
>; Monica Marcel <
m.marcel@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Post conversation follow-up
 
Hello Marisa, 
Thank you for meeting with the team last week. As a newer consultant here at LCW I really appreciated learning about the relationship Progressive and LCW built along with your successes.  Kudos on being named #1 on Forbes list of America’s Best Employers for Diversity 2022! Interesting fact, LCW has worked with 2 of the 5 top companies on the list.
Would you be able to reply to the areas highlighted in the table? Our goal is to have this done quickly, we are tentatively hoping by end of next week. 
I am off but will be monitoring emails as I know this is something your group would like to get completed ASAP. I will also be sending over an estimated quote/sow for the work by tomorrow. 
Thank you 
Tahitia
 
Module
Concern
Suggested change/recommendations
Managing with Intercultural Competence
Slide 5 - intercultural development continuum: Minimization example - "It makes no difference to me if she's from the North or the South, single, married or divorced, black or white, or what religion she belongs to" 
The Progressive Team will share the language that they have used in other areas with the LCW team.
 
See above suggestion
Managing with Intercultural Competence
Slide 6:  "Men and women often analyze issues differently and communicate about them differently.  I think a group can be more creative if these differences are put to good use"
The Progressive Team will share the language that they have used in other areas with the LCW team.
  
See above suggestion
Evaluating Talent
Page 13: Insight highlights Thomas Kochman’s work on “Black and White Styles in Conflict,” – based on his research, Kochman states that “black and white Americans use two different communication styles for establishing the same goal of trust in communication: truth over peace and peace over truth.”  
It is part of the voiceover, and when the insight is clicked this shows
LCW checking for replacement references
LCW will update with new text and audio as needed
*Marisa were there any concerns regarding the second reference which is about gender difference? We can look for a replacement there too if that would be helpful.
  
Good catch, yes, probably so.  If you can look at alternatives, that would be great
Providing Opportunity
Page 11: 
2nd example– “When we hear dissent from someone from a different race, it provokes more thought than when it comes from someone of our race.” - article citation from Scientific American, “How Diversity Made Us Smarter.” Oct. 2014.   
 
4th example: “The groups with racial diversity significantly outperformed the group with no racial diversity. Being with similar people leads us to think we all hold the same information and share the same perspective. This perspective, which stopped the all-white groups from effectively processing the information, is what hinders creativity and innovation. This is a great reminder as we look for ways to promote from within or staff our teams.” –“Surface level diversity and decision-making in groups: when does deep level similarity help?”
LCW checking for replacement references
LCW will update with new text and audio as needed
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
------------------------------------------------------

body:
Hi Tahitia,
 
We haven’t had a chance to talk since the announcement of your departure was shared with the team. I just wanted to say I really appreciate you and know you will be missed! I know we have quite a while before you actually leave, but I just wanted to share this with you now!

Hi all,
 
You should be seeing the invitation for our July client event in your inboxes now! I’ve copied it below in case you missed it. This message was sent to our client list minus any opt-outs that were noted. Please remember that this does not need to replace your personal invites; 
if there are clients you would like to make sure attend, please use this message as an opportunity to personally invite them to register.
 
Thank you again for your help!
 
Jake
 
 
Join us for an LCW client event: 
Preparing for Hispanic Heritage Month
 
Reserve your seat for this session now!
 
 
You've been selected by an LCW staff member for an exclusive invite to this LCW client event!
 
Throughout this one-hour event, we'll explore key experiences that tend to impact your Latinx colleagues, and share proven strategies for building cultural competence for stronger connections with the Latinx community... not only in time for Hispanic Heritage Month, but all-year-long. 
This unique event allows participants to experience LCW training activities and come together for meaningful discussion. Together we will: 
Gain insight into the depth and rich history of the Latinx community
Examine some experiences that tend to shape the identity of many who identify as members of this culture
Discuss strategies for making the Latinx community feel seen, valued, and respected all-year-long
This session is only available by invite! Use the registration link provided in this email and 
reserve up to 3 seats
 for your organization.
Make sure to reserve your seat now; seats for this session are available on a first-come basis!

Subject:
 RE: Action Requested by EOD 7/13 - Client event invites
 
Hi all,
 
You should be seeing the invitation for our July client event in your inboxes now! I’ve copied it below in case you missed it. This message was sent to our client list minus any opt-outs that were noted. Please remember that this does not need to replace your personal invites; 
if there are clients you would like to make sure attend, please use this message as an opportunity to personally invite them to register.
 
Thank you again for your help!
 
Jake
 
 
Join us for an LCW client event: 
Preparing for Hispanic Heritage Month
 
Reserve your seat for this session now!
 
 
You've been selected by an LCW staff member for an exclusive invite to this LCW client event!
 
Throughout this one-hour event, we'll explore key experiences that tend to impact your Latinx colleagues, and share proven strategies for building cultural competence for stronger connections with the Latinx community... not only in time for Hispanic Heritage Month, but all-year-long. 
This unique event allows participants to experience LCW training activities and come together for meaningful discussion. Together we will: 
Gain insight into the depth and rich history of the Latinx community
Examine some experiences that tend to shape the identity of many who identify as members of this culture
Discuss strategies for making the Latinx community feel seen, valued, and respected all-year-long
This session is only available by invite! Use the registration link provided in this email and 
reserve up to 3 seats
 for your organization.
Make sure to reserve your seat now; seats for this session are available on a first-come basis!

From:

c.adams@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, July 19, 2022 12:00 PM
To:
 Office <
office@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Staff Announcement
 
Team -
 
We wanted to inform you all that Tahitia Timmons is resigning her position at LCW, effective
 end of 
August.
 
While we hate seeing Tahitia leave LCW we are thrilled for her reasoning – she has decided to start her own consulting company to focus on her personal and professional passion: Health Equity. We could not be happier for Tahitia’s next chapter.
 
The few months that Tahitia has been with LCW have been wonderful, and too short. She freely offered her unique perspective and her deep expertise internally and performed with considerable aplomb with our clients. She is knowledgeable, unflappable, and sharing. She contributed to our success by challenging the status quo and offering potential solutions based on her broad experiences in the field. She never critiqued a process or approach without also offering a different perspective as a way forward. That was always greatly appreciated.
 
Tahitia will spend the next few weeks transitioning her work. More information will follow.
 
Alisa and I wish Tahitia the very best and are happy that her circumstances have presented her with this amazing opportunity, and we strongly support her striking out on her own. Please join us in congratulating Tahitia on this exciting move.
 
Best,
 
Alisa/Chuck
 
 
______________________________________
Chuck Adams 
Co-CEO and Managing Principal
 
LCW
100 South Saunders Rd, Suite 150
Lake Forest, IL 60045 USA

 Please Join me July 28th - Hispanic Heritage Month Special Client Preview!

Hello, 
Please join me July 28
th
 , with my colleague Ada Vargas, as we prepare for Hispanic Heritage Month. 
We will provide a special preview of two LCWs educational offerings: Understanding the Latinx Experience in America and Spotlight on the Latinx Community. You can use the registration link to 
reserve up to 3 seats
 and don’t forget to schedule time with me so we can bring one of these offerings to your organization. 
See you on the 28
th
!
Tahitia Timmons
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Join us for an LCW client event: 
Preparing for Hispanic Heritage Month
 
Reserve your seat for this session now!
 
 
You've been selected by an LCW staff member for an exclusive invite to this LCW client event!
 
Throughout this one-hour event, we'll explore key experiences that tend to impact your Latinx colleagues, and share proven strategies for building cultural competence for stronger connections with the Latinx community... not only in time for Hispanic Heritage Month, but all-year-long. 
This unique event allows participants to experience LCW training activities and come together for meaningful discussion. Together we will: 
Gain insight into the depth and rich history of the Latinx community
Examine some experiences that tend to shape the identity of many who identify as members of this culture
Discuss strategies for making the Latinx community feel seen, valued, and respected all-year-long
This session is only available by invite! Use the registration link provided in this email and 
reserve up to 3 seats
 for your organization.
Make sure to reserve your seat now; seats for this session are available on a first-come basis!

 Office <
office@lcwmail.com

Subject:
 Staff Announcement
 
Team -
 
We wanted to inform you all that Tahitia Timmons is resigning her position at LCW, effective
 end of 
August.
 
While we hate seeing Tahitia leave LCW we are thrilled for her reasoning – she has decided to start her own consulting company to focus on her personal and professional passion: Health Equity. We could not be happier for Tahitia’s next chapter.
 
The few months that Tahitia has been with LCW have been wonderful, and too short. She freely offered her unique perspective and her deep expertise internally and performed with considerable aplomb with our clients. She is knowledgeable, unflappable, and sharing. She contributed to our success by challenging the status quo and offering potential solutions based on her broad experiences in the field. She never critiqued a process or approach without also offering a different perspective as a way forward. That was always greatly appreciated.
 
Tahitia will spend the next few weeks transitioning her work. More information will follow.
 
Alisa and I wish Tahitia the very best and are happy that her circumstances have presented her with this amazing opportunity, and we strongly support her striking out on her own. Please join us in congratulating Tahitia on this exciting move.
 
Best,
 
Alisa/Chuck
 
 
______________________________________

subject: Re: LCW: Response to Florida's HB7
body:
You might start by sending your client this link to LCW's public response, Melonya, and then if they have more specific questions, Sarah's and Tahitia's notes have great examples.
https://languageandculture.com/a-note-from-lcw-leadership-statement-on-floridas-stop-woke-act/
From:
 Tahitia Timmons <t.timmons@lcwmail.com>
Sent:
 Tuesday, July 19, 2022 3:38 PM
To:
 Melonya Johnson <m.johnson@lcwmail.com>; Training <training@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Re: LCW: Response to Florida's HB7
 
 
Hi Melonya,
I think clients appear to be approaching it multiple ways:
Add a disclaimer 
Not make it a mandatory training
Have their legal team review and point to any potential risk items
Make language/wording changes in collaboration with us (so overall message isn’t loss) 
Wait and see approach - there is still a case that needs to be discussed from business owners which would change this. They filed an injunction under free speech (corporate application) 
https://reason.com/2022/06/27/new-complaint-challenges-limits-to-corporate-speech-enacted-by-floridas-stop-woke-act/?amp
That said J&J also had to deal with this and I believe they utilized the disclaimer method. - Dan can discuss them more. The big differences with this versus other types of similar state acts are this one also targets private business AND it's in a state where many businesses will set up because of friendly tax laws. 
Whatever insight I can lend happy to help. 
Thanks 
Tahitia 
Get 
Outlook for iOS
From:
 Melonya Johnson <m.johnson@lcwmail.com>
Sent:
 Tuesday, July 19, 2022 3:57:10 PM
To:
 Training <training@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 LCW: Response to Florida's HB7
 
 
Greetings,
 
My client has a question regarding the legislation change that happened in Florida with HB7.  My client asked the following, “Can you share how your organization has managed through this to ensure this training isn’t violating this FL act?  
 
She said that she is happy to jump on a call if you feel it would be helpful.
 
Thank you!
Melonya
 
 
------------------------------------------------------

Consultant (Buffalo, NY)

subject: LCW Event: Let's talk about BIPOC DEI Practitioner Mental Health
body:
Join the conversation by attending this live stream where we will discuss the unique challenges facing BIPOC DEI practitioners.
 
 
 
Register to attend the live stream!
 
Join the conversation with LCW!
Description:
 
Did you know that July is BIPOC Mental Health Awareness Month? BIPOC Mental Health Awareness Month aims to increase visibility of the ways historically disenfranchised, marginalized, or oppressed racial and ethnic groups face unique mental health challenges.
LCW’s Larry Baker and Melonya Johnson take this conversation further, specifically examining the challenges facing BIPOC DEI practitioners as they discuss inequality, racism, and oppression on a daily basis, while often still enduring it in the workplace. 
You can join the conversation by attending this complimentary live stream session. Whether you’re a practitioner, ally, or leader, we invite you to join this discussion and bring your questions for our experts.
Details:
 
July 26th | 3pm CST (Q&A to follow)
Please use the button above to register. We'll see you there!

subject: Follow up
body:
Hello, 
Happy “Touchbase Tuesday”!  I have Arlene’s documents and would like to begin to finalize the Panel discussion for the Black Executive Sponsor Program. 
I wanted to follow up on a few items: 
Would you be able to introduce my group here to Jason who I have listed as my main contact for both the Black Executive and Latinx Executive programs, so we can create a meeting cadence 
The names of the two IDIs that need to be completed (I will send a separate SOW so we can get those done)
How many participants will be in the Latinx program – Is there crossover between the two groups? I am attempting to get a total number of IDIs that group may need. 
 
I can also work with Jason to get this information – I just would need an introduction. 
 
Thank you 
Tahitia
 
 
------------------------------------------------------

Team -
 
We wanted to inform you all that Tahitia Timmons is resigning her position at LCW, effective
 end of 
August.
 
While we hate seeing Tahitia leave LCW we are thrilled for her reasoning – she has decided to start her own consulting company to focus on her personal and professional passion: Health Equity. We could not be happier for Tahitia’s next chapter.
 
The few months that Tahitia has been with LCW have been wonderful, and too short. She freely offered her unique perspective and her deep expertise internally and performed with considerable aplomb with our clients. She is knowledgeable, unflappable, and sharing. She contributed to our success by challenging the status quo and offering potential solutions based on her broad experiences in the field. She never critiqued a process or approach without also offering a different perspective as a way forward. That was always greatly appreciated.
 
Tahitia will spend the next few weeks transitioning her work. More information will follow.
 
Alisa and I wish Tahitia the very best and are happy that her circumstances have presented her with this amazing opportunity, and we strongly support her striking out on her own. Please join us in congratulating Tahitia on this exciting move.
 
Best,
 
Alisa/Chuck

Team – 
 
We wanted to inform you all that Tahitia Timmons is resigning her position at LCW, effective August 12. While we hate seeing Tahitia leave LCW we are thrilled for her reasoning – she has decided to start her own consulting company to focus on her personal and professional passion: Health Equity. We could not be happier for Tahitia’s next chapter.
 
The few months that Tahitia has been with LCW have been wonderful, and too short. She freely offered her unique perspectives and her deep expertise internally, and performed with considerable aplomb with our clients. She is knowledgeable, unflappable, and sharing. She contributed to our success by challenging the status quo and offering potential solutions based on her broad experiences in the field. She never critiqued a process or approach without also offering a different perspective as a way forward. That was always greatly appreciated.
 
Tahitia will spend the next few weeks transitioning her work. More information will follow.
 
Alisa and I wish Tahitia the very best and are happy that her circumstances have presented her with this amazing opportunity, and we strongly support her striking out on her own.

 Danaher, Redhouse and LCW Project
 
Hi Chuck and Dan, 
I have included Dan in the conversation regarding Danaher and  added a zip file on our dropbox (ones from Arlene) . The Link is here 
https://www.dropbox.com/s/hymbz1d4510lk33/DO_NOT_EDIT_%20REMOVE_Files_B_A_E_S_Program%20.zip?dl=0
  Do you know if there is a way to restrict access to that particular folder other then locking editing access since we did not create this content or should we just share Arlene’s dropbox as needed? I was not sure what best practice is here for this type of work. 
My plan was to follow up with Nicole once I have your input.  Also do we want to just all get together briefly to walk Dan through this project? I gave him a semi high level overview of the request. 
 
Invoicing and SOW
For this client I have in my notes we had not determined whether we were invoicing Danaher or Arlene - Redhouse Performance Consulting (RPC).  However, I see that Arlene has since requested we invoice Danaher directly during the time she is out (8 weeks). Nicole Wormley was checking to see if we were still 
active in their system
 – we will need to verify that as I did not see an invoice in 2021.  
 
Did you discuss any costs related to this project with Arlene? I know they want us to take over and do Session 3 of the program and work with Jason Butler at Danaher to support initiate the Latinx program and I can price those items out, but is there a price point we are staying within? This would help with writing that SOW. 
 
LCW Actionable Request 
Black Executive Sponsorship Program (Redhouse Performance Consulting, LLC)
Develop and anchor a panel discussion with Danaher Board Member Shane Sanders and a Black Female Executive (TBD).
Request is to have this lead by a Black female (LCW or collaborate an external pick) 
Target delivery is mid/late 3Q.  
Program format can be a hybrid live/virtual.  
LCW and at least one panelist is live; the other panelist(s) can have interviews pre-recorded.  
The target audience are Danaher’s senior executive leadership team members who are actively sponsoring mid-career Black executives.  
Deliver Two IDIs and debrief
Latinx Executive Sponsorship Program 
Assist/Support the initiation of a similar rollout of the Latinx program which is being led by Sr. Director Corp D+I (Needs to be built or perhaps this is the CCLP with a look and feel like Redhouse’s stuff since the plan is to hand this back to Arlene? 
 
Executive Coaching request
Chuck you were checking availability or the possibility of another Black male providing executive coaching for the Sr. Director Corp D+I.   
 
Thank you 
 
------------------------------------------------------
Tahitia Timmons

Lake Forest, IL 60045

Subject:
 DHR Exec Sponsorship Program & LCW 
 
Hi Nicole,
 
Per our meeting last Friday, I have moved forward with contacting Charles (Chuck) Adams at LCW, Redhouse's most trusted partner in all things DEI.   I have worked with Chuck and many others at the firm for over 12 years!  Furthermore, several LCW virtual DEI trainings are in Danaher's online library.
 
LCW has agreed to take the lead in the design and execution of session 3 for the Black Asso. Exec Sponsorship Program.   I also requested LCW’s assistance in providing meaningful content and facilitation for session 2 of the Latin X Executive Sponsorship Program (BTW-  It took considerable effort to convince Jason, that LCW is needed to deliver a meaningful and believable Latin X program for the sponsors.)  My email (attached below) also mentions the possibility of providing executive coaching and support.
 
Chuck is included on this email and will reach out to you separately to ensure that his team is aligned with your understanding and expectations.   Given that I/Redhouse will be pausing operations for 6-8 weeks, I recommended that LCW prepare a brief proposal and execute an agreement/statement of work directly with Danaher Corp D+I.   Hoping LCW’s previous extensive work with Corporate D+I will help make the contracting process move quickly.
 
I will leave it to the two of you to correct and realign the understanding as needed.  I know that I’m passing the baton on these projects to a team who will deliver with excellence.  
 
Best regards,
Arlene F. Roane (She/Her)
Creating spaces where people BELIEVE they are valued and appreciated.
Redhouse Performance Consulting, LLC

From:

 Monday, June 27, 2022 8:39 AM
To:
 'Chuck Adams' <
c.adams@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Danaher Corp D+I Projects 
 
Hello Chuck,
 
Hope your summer is off to a good start. 
 
I’m reaching out to request your assistance and leadership on several initiatives with Danaher Corp D+I.  I am scheduled to have major surgery on July 13
th
 and would be greatly relieved and encouraged if LCW/you were to step in.   I have already received approval from the CDO, Nicole Wormley.  The projects include:
 
Black Associate Executive Sponsorship Program – This program was initiated in 3Q2021.  Redhouse/I designed and led the executive sponsors thru a process that included the IDI/1x1 in-depth briefings and 2 group learning sessions exploring the significant cultural and day-to-day experiences of Blacks in corporate roles.  Developing and anchoring a panel discussion with Danaher Board Member Shane Sanders and a Black Female Executive (TBD).  LCW can take the lead or we could collaborate on recruiting the Black female.  The target delivery is mid/late 3Q.  The program format can be a hybrid live/virtual.  You and at least one panelist is live; the other panelist(s) can have interviews pre-recorded.  The target audience are Danaher’s senior executive leadership team members who are actively sponsoring mid-career Black executives.  
 
Latin X Executive Sponsorship Program – This program is being initiated now and is intended to follow the same trajectory as the Black Exec Sponsorship Prgm (ESP).  The Sr. Dir Corp D+I (a Black male) is responsible needs assistance in finding and delivering content similar to what was presented in the Black ESP.   LCW’s depth and breadth of content and experienced facilitation is sorely needed.  Target delivery is early to mid 3Q
 
Additionally,  Nicole (the CDO) would like to discuss the possibility of having you (or another Black male) provide executive coaching for the Sr. Director Corp D+I.  I can share more about this when we talk.   I will also brief you on other Redhouse projects at Danaher.  While ultimately I anticipate recovering and getting back to full engagement by  early 4Q, I need to prepare for the possibility of a longer recouperation.
 
I am hoping that we can find time to meet this week. I am available any day EXCEPT Wednesday.  I will be infinitely flexible including early mornings and evenings.  
 
Thank you in advance.
 
Best regards,
Arlene F. Roane (She/Her)
Creating spaces where people BELIEVE they are valued and appreciated.
Redhouse Performance Consulting, LLC
www.redhousepc.com
 
Mobile US 1.513.290.6569

Subject:
 Danaher, Redhouse and LCW Project
 
Hi Chuck and Dan, 
I have included Dan in the conversation regarding Danaher and  added a zip file on our dropbox (ones from Arlene) . The Link is here 
https://www.dropbox.com/s/hymbz1d4510lk33/DO_NOT_EDIT_%20REMOVE_Files_B_A_E_S_Program%20.zip?dl=0
  Do you know if there is a way to restrict access to that particular folder other then locking editing access since we did not create this content or should we just share Arlene’s dropbox as needed? I was not sure what best practice is here for this type of work. 
My plan was to follow up with Nicole once I have your input.  Also do we want to just all get together briefly to walk Dan through this project? I gave him a semi high level overview of the request. 
 
Invoicing and SOW
For this client I have in my notes we had not determined whether we were invoicing Danaher or Arlene - Redhouse Performance Consulting (RPC).  However, I see that Arlene has since requested we invoice Danaher directly during the time she is out (8 weeks). Nicole Wormley was checking to see if we were still 
active in their system
 – we will need to verify that as I did not see an invoice in 2021.  
 
Did you discuss any costs related to this project with Arlene? I know they want us to take over and do Session 3 of the program and work with Jason Butler at Danaher to support initiate the Latinx program and I can price those items out, but is there a price point we are staying within? This would help with writing that SOW. 
 
LCW Actionable Request 
Black Executive Sponsorship Program (Redhouse Performance Consulting, LLC)
Develop and anchor a panel discussion with Danaher Board Member Shane Sanders and a Black Female Executive (TBD).
Request is to have this lead by a Black female (LCW or collaborate an external pick) 
Target delivery is mid/late 3Q.  
Program format can be a hybrid live/virtual.  
LCW and at least one panelist is live; the other panelist(s) can have interviews pre-recorded.  
The target audience are Danaher’s senior executive leadership team members who are actively sponsoring mid-career Black executives.  
Deliver Two IDIs and debrief
Latinx Executive Sponsorship Program 
Assist/Support the initiation of a similar rollout of the Latinx program which is being led by Sr. Director Corp D+I (Needs to be built or perhaps this is the CCLP with a look and feel like Redhouse’s stuff since the plan is to hand this back to Arlene? 
 
Executive Coaching request
Chuck you were checking availability or the possibility of another Black male providing executive coaching for the Sr. Director Corp D+I.   
 
Thank you 
 
------------------------------------------------------
Tahitia Timmons

Lake Forest, IL 60045

Hi Nicole,
 
Per our meeting last Friday, I have moved forward with contacting Charles (Chuck) Adams at LCW, Redhouse's most trusted partner in all things DEI.   I have worked with Chuck and many others at the firm for over 12 years!  Furthermore, several LCW virtual DEI trainings are in Danaher's online library.
 
LCW has agreed to take the lead in the design and execution of session 3 for the Black Asso. Exec Sponsorship Program.   I also requested LCW’s assistance in providing meaningful content and facilitation for session 2 of the Latin X Executive Sponsorship Program (BTW-  It took considerable effort to convince Jason, that LCW is needed to deliver a meaningful and believable Latin X program for the sponsors.)  My email (attached below) also mentions the possibility of providing executive coaching and support.
 
Chuck is included on this email and will reach out to you separately to ensure that his team is aligned with your understanding and expectations.   Given that I/Redhouse will be pausing operations for 6-8 weeks, I recommended that LCW prepare a brief proposal and execute an agreement/statement of work directly with Danaher Corp D+I.   Hoping LCW’s previous extensive work with Corporate D+I will help make the contracting process move quickly.
 
I will leave it to the two of you to correct and realign the understanding as needed.  I know that I’m passing the baton on these projects to a team who will deliver with excellence.

__________________________
 
Team – 
 
We wanted to inform you all that Tahitia Timmons is resigning her position at LCW, effective August 12. While we hate seeing Tahitia leave LCW we are thrilled for her reasoning – she has decided to start her own consulting company to focus on her personal and professional passion: Health Equity. We could not be happier for Tahitia’s next chapter.
 
The few months that Tahitia has been with LCW have been wonderful, and too short. She freely offered her unique perspectives and her deep expertise internally, and performed with considerable aplomb with our clients. She is knowledgeable, unflappable, and sharing. She contributed to our success by challenging the status quo and offering potential solutions based on her broad experiences in the field. She never critiqued a process or approach without also offering a different perspective as a way forward. That was always greatly appreciated.
 
Tahitia will spend the next few weeks transitioning her work. More information will follow.
 
Alisa and I wish Tahitia the very best and are happy that her circumstances have presented her with this amazing opportunity, and we strongly support her striking out on her own. 
 
 
______________________________________
Chuck Adams 
Co-CEO and Managing Principal
 
LCW
100 South Saunders Rd, Suite 150
Lake Forest, IL 60045 USA

+1.773.938.4285
Mobile: +1.630.373.5068

subject: Re: For Review: Staff Announcement
body:
Thank you, I truly appreciate everyone here and this is very nice of y’all to say! 
Tahitia 
Get 
Outlook for iOS
From:
 Chuck Adams <c.adams@lcwmail.com>
Sent:
 Monday, July 18, 2022 4:46:55 PM
To:
 Tahitia Timmons <t.timmons@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Alisa Kolodizner <a.kolodizner@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 For Review: Staff Announcement
 
 
Let me know any edits you’d make. ~chuck
__________________________
 
Team – 
 
We wanted to inform you all that Tahitia Timmons is resigning her position at LCW, effective August 12. While we hate seeing Tahitia leave LCW we are thrilled for her reasoning – she has decided to start her own consulting company to focus on her personal and professional passion: Health Equity. We could not be happier for Tahitia’s next chapter.
 
The few months that Tahitia has been with LCW have been wonderful, and too short. She freely offered her unique perspectives and her deep expertise internally, and performed with considerable aplomb with our clients. She is knowledgeable, unflappable, and sharing. She contributed to our success by challenging the status quo and offering potential solutions based on her broad experiences in the field. She never critiqued a process or approach without also offering a different perspective as a way forward. That was always greatly appreciated.
 
Tahitia will spend the next few weeks transitioning her work. More information will follow.
 
Alisa and I wish Tahitia the very best and are happy that her circumstances have presented her with this amazing opportunity, and we strongly support her striking out on her own. 
 
 
______________________________________
Chuck Adams 
Co-CEO and Managing Principal
 
LCW

Lake Forest, IL 60045 USA

subject: Any availability this week or next to meet
body:
Hi Karen, 
Following up from our last email. I have been discussing your need finish training the rest of your group and willingness to perhaps do it as an 
e-learning
. Currently we do not have longer offerings as e-modules, just the shorter pieces of content. However, we are looking at creating a LMS with a library of LCW content and interested in finding out if there is client interest in having this, price points, and what might be a value add. We have a plan to soft launch in December (if there is enough interest)  Do you have any 
availability to talk with the Director of Design (Kelly
) and myself here either this week or next about 30 minutes? I was thinking that if we can get the MUB (TTT) in here that might make this a potential fix for your training issue. 
Let me know your thoughts and if we can get something on the books with Kelly. 
Thank you 
 
------------------------------------------------------
Tahitia Timmons

body:

Best!!

Hi Kelly, 
I added my updates.  The slide 6 probably is the one that gives me a little pause. There is no real way of explaining this concept without mentioning race – so since the law states it has to shows both perspectives and be neutral I think this reads the best but ……the concept about “novel ideas” feels a bit weird. 
 
Anyway have a great time away!
Tahitia

From:

k.salek@lcwmail.com
>

 Monday, July 11, 2022 11:01 AM

 Tahitia Timmons <

m.marcel@lcwmail.com

Subject:
 [EXTERNAL] RE: Post conversation follow-up
 
Good day Tahitia and Marisa - 
In addition to the information below, there are a few things that needs attention: 
 
Module 2: Managing w/Intercultural Competence
Slide 5
…Being that the suggested text not only appears onscreen, but every example (words in the quotes) does have the audio narrated. If we change this one, we will either need to have the voiceover talent rerecord (need to find out availability and cost) or we can remove all the audio pieces from the IDI interaction slides? 
Thoughts?
  
I believe removing the voice over from all is the best way to go.
 
Slide 5: Was this the suggested text we talked about:
It makes no difference to me if my 
teammates 
have cultural differences 
she is from the North or the South, single, married or divorced, thin or fat, black or white, or what religion she belongs to. She’s one of us, and
 
as long as we 
let her know that, we 
can all work together.  
That could work, or here’s what we’ve used elsewhere: “My team members’ cultural backgrounds don’t make any difference to me. We’re part of the same team working toward the same business goals, and that’s all we need to work well together”  
 
 
On 
slide 6
, here is what I have written down…
Men and women often
 
Employees
 People 
may analyze issues 
differently
 and communicate about them differently.  I think a group can be more creative if these differences are put to good use.
 (intercultural)  
I would just use “people” vs “employees”.  We can also remove the extra “differently”
 
Module 5: Evaluating Talent
For the slide that references Kochman’s work is the one shown below. If we change out the references, I do believe that we will also need to exclude or cut the red-marked audio as well. Please advise.   
Yes, I agree.
 
 
From:
 Tahitia Timmons <
t.timmons@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Monday, July 11, 2022 11:06 AM
To:
 
Marisa_Afzali@Progressive.com
Cc:
 Kelly Salek <
k.salek@lcwmail.com
>; Monica Marcel <
m.marcel@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Post conversation follow-up
 
Hello Marisa, 
Thank you for meeting with the team last week. As a newer consultant here at LCW I really appreciated learning about the relationship Progressive and LCW built along with your successes.  Kudos on being named #1 on Forbes list of America’s Best Employers for Diversity 2022! Interesting fact, LCW has worked with 2 of the 5 top companies on the list.
Would you be able to reply to the areas highlighted in the table? Our goal is to have this done quickly, we are tentatively hoping by end of next week. 
I am off but will be monitoring emails as I know this is something your group would like to get completed ASAP. I will also be sending over an estimated quote/sow for the work by tomorrow. 
Thank you 
Tahitia
 
Module
Concern
Suggested change/recommendations
Managing with Intercultural Competence
Slide 5 - intercultural development continuum: Minimization example - "It makes no difference to me if she's from the North or the South, single, married or divorced, black or white, or what religion she belongs to" 
The Progressive Team will share the language that they have used in other areas with the LCW team.
 
See above suggestion
Managing with Intercultural Competence
Slide 6:  "Men and women often analyze issues differently and communicate about them differently.  I think a group can be more creative if these differences are put to good use"
The Progressive Team will share the language that they have used in other areas with the LCW team.
  
See above suggestion
Evaluating Talent
Page 13: Insight highlights Thomas Kochman’s work on “Black and White Styles in Conflict,” – based on his research, Kochman states that “black and white Americans use two different communication styles for establishing the same goal of trust in communication: truth over peace and peace over truth.”  
It is part of the voiceover, and when the insight is clicked this shows
LCW checking for replacement references
LCW will update with new text and audio as needed
*Marisa were there any concerns regarding the second reference which is about gender difference? We can look for a replacement there too if that would be helpful.
  
Good catch, yes, probably so.  If you can look at alternatives, that would be great
Providing Opportunity
Page 11: 
2nd example– “When we hear dissent from someone from a different race, it provokes more thought than when it comes from someone of our race.” - article citation from Scientific American, “How Diversity Made Us Smarter.” Oct. 2014.   
 
4th example: “The groups with racial diversity significantly outperformed the group with no racial diversity. Being with similar people leads us to think we all hold the same information and share the same perspective. This perspective, which stopped the all-white groups from effectively processing the information, is what hinders creativity and innovation. This is a great reminder as we look for ways to promote from within or staff our teams.” –“Surface level diversity and decision-making in groups: when does deep level similarity help?”
LCW checking for replacement references
LCW will update with new text and audio as needed
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
------------------------------------------------------
Tahitia Timmons

Lake Forest, IL 60045

subject: RE: JTI follow-up meeting
body:
Hi Victor, 
No problem is there a particular date that you think these two may be given in q3 and 4or if maybe you prefer moving one to Q1 2023 and spreading out the remaining 3 that way? I know that JTI has already paid for these.  I just want to make sure that on the internal side you also can promote these events appropriately. My guess is you are looking to deliver 1 maybe in Aug/September, then October and December or maybe January 2023? 
Feel free to suggest some dates and we can chat for maybe 30 around what might work. 
How Culture Influences Communication Style (Victor Carbonell – Race & Ethnicity Pillar – point of contact for this session)
Navigating Global Cultures (Victor Carbonell – Race & Ethnicity Pillar – point of contact for this session)
Thanks

subject: Accreditation, certificates, certifications info
body:
Hi Alisa, 
I poked around and here are some great resources about the process. ICE has a nice summary of the differences – probably the best bet is to build it with a university versus owning that process. 
An example of this was Howard University and Coach Diversity (I think they are on hold right now because of funding)
https://rollingout.com/2019/08/29/howard-university-introduces-new-executive-diversity-coaching-program/
 
The Institute for Credentialing Excellence (I.C.E)
https://www.credentialingexcellence.org/Accreditation/New-to-Accreditation/Certificate-vs-Certification
 
American National Standards Institute (ANSI)
https://www.standardsportal.org/usa_en/resources/usaccreditation_bodies.aspx
 
Anyway hope this is useful

Good day Tahitia and Marisa - 
In addition to the information below, there are a few things that needs attention: 
 
Module 2: Managing w/Intercultural Competence
Slide 5
…Being that the suggested text not only appears onscreen, but every example (words in the quotes) does have the audio narrated. If we change this one, we will either need to have the voiceover talent rerecord (need to find out availability and cost) or we can remove all the audio pieces from the IDI interaction slides? 
Thoughts?
  
I believe removing the voice over from all is the best way to go.
 
Slide 5: Was this the suggested text we talked about:
It makes no difference to me if my 
teammates 
have cultural differences 
she is from the North or the South, single, married or divorced, thin or fat, black or white, or what religion she belongs to. She’s one of us, and
 
as long as we 
let her know that, we 
can all work together.  
That could work, or here’s what we’ve used elsewhere: “My team members’ cultural backgrounds don’t make any difference to me. We’re part of the same team working toward the same business goals, and that’s all we need to work well together”  
 
 
On 
slide 6
, here is what I have written down…
Men and women often
 
Employees
 People 
may analyze issues 
differently
 and communicate about them differently.  I think a group can be more creative if these differences are put to good use.
 (intercultural)  
I would just use “people” vs “employees”.  We can also remove the extra “differently”
 
Module 5: Evaluating Talent
For the slide that references Kochman’s work is the one shown below. If we change out the references, I do believe that we will also need to exclude or cut the red-marked audio as well. Please advise.   
Yes, I agree.
 
 
From:
 Tahitia Timmons <
t.timmons@lcwmail.com
>
